course.title: AP®︎/College Calculus AB
course.description: Learn AP®︎ Calculus AB—everything you need to know about limits, derivatives, and integrals to pass the AP® test.

units.title: Limits and continuity
units.description: Limits describe the behavior of a function as we approach a certain input value, regardless of the function's actual value there. Continuity requires that the behavior of a function around a point matches the function's value at that point. These simple yet powerful ideas play a major role in all of calculus.

topics.title: About the course

contents.title: Khan Academy in the classroom
contents.description: Bill Scott uses Khan Academy to teach AP Calculus at Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts, and he’s part of the teaching team that helped develop Khan Academy’s AP lessons. Phillips Academy was one of the first schools to teach AP nearly 60 years ago.

keyMoments.label: Introduction and background
Discovering the coaching platform
Changing the way of teaching
Positive outcomes

subtitles.text:

that for

or

And then suddenly there's

contents.title: Sal interviews the AP Calculus Lead at College Board
contents.description: In this video, Sal interviews Ben Hedrick, the AP Calculus Lead at College Board. They discuss the AP Calculus exam's focus on conceptual understanding, the importance of mastering core topics like derivatives and integrals, and the value of practicing with past exams. Ben also advises students to relax and approach the exam as just another test.

keyMoments.label: Introduction and background of interviewees
Goals of the AP Calculus exam
Advice for preparing for the exam
Topics to focus on
Advice for using a calculator on the exam
Advice for tackling the free response section
Parting words and resources

contents.title: What to know before taking calculus
contents.description: So you're about to take AP Calculus, eh?  Here's a summary of what you should know going into it.

topics.title: Defining limits and using limit notation

contents.title: Limits intro
contents.description: In this video, we learn about limits, a fundamental concept in calculus. Limits help us understand what a function approaches as the input gets closer to a certain value, even when the function is undefined at that point. The video demonstrates this concept using two examples with different functions.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to the concept of a limit
Example of a function with a discontinuity at x=1
Finding the limit as x approaches 1
Example of a function with a discontinuity at x=2
Finding the limit as x approaches 2

contents.title: Limits intro
contents.description: Limits describe how a function behaves near a point, instead of at that point. This simple yet powerful idea is the basis of all of calculus.

contents.title: Limits intro
contents.description: Practice finding simple limits and working with limit notation.

topics.title: Estimating limit values from graphs

contents.title: Estimating limit values from graphs
contents.description: In this video, we learn to estimate limit values from graphs by observing the function's behavior as x approaches a value from both left and right sides. If the function approaches the same value from both sides, the limit exists. If it approaches different values or is unbounded, the limit doesn't exist.

contents.title: Unbounded limits
contents.description: This video discusses estimating limit values from graphs, focusing on two functions: y = 1/x² and y = 1/x. For y = 1/x², the limit is unbounded as x approaches 0, since the function increases without bound. For y = 1/x, the limit doesn't exist as x approaches 0, since it's unbounded in opposite directions.

keyMoments.label: Introduction and graph of y=1/x^2
Finding the limit of 1/x^2 as x approaches zero
Explanation of unbounded limit
Introduction and graph of y=1/x
Finding the limit of 1/x as x approaches zero
Explanation of why the limit does not exist

contents.title: Estimating limit values from graphs
contents.description: The best way to start reasoning about limits is using graphs. Learn how we analyze a limit graphically and see cases where a limit doesn't exist.

contents.title: Estimating limit values from graphs
contents.description: Practice finding two sided limits by looking at graphs.

contents.title: One-sided limits from graphs
contents.description: A one-sided limit is the value the function approaches as the x-values approach the limit from *one side only*. For example, f(x)=|x|/x returns -1 for negative numbers, 1 for positive numbers, and isn't defined for 0. The one-sided *right* limit of f at x=0 is 1, and the one-sided *left* limit at x=0 is -1.

contents.title: One-sided limits from graphs: asymptote
contents.description: This video explores estimating one-sided limit values from graphs. As x approaches 6 from the left, the function becomes unbounded with an asymptote, making the left-sided limit nonexistent. However, when approaching 6 from the right, the function approaches -3, indicating that the right-handed limit exists. Sal's analysis highlights the importance of understanding limits from both sides.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to the problem of finding the limit of g of x
Examining the function from the left side of x=6
Conclusion that the left-handed limit does not exist
Examining the function from the right side of x=6
Conclusion that the right-handed limit is -3

contents.title: Connecting limits and graphical behavior
contents.description: Usually when we analyze a function's limits from its graph, we are looking at the more "interesting" points. It's important to remember that you can talk about the function's value at any point. Also, a description of a limit can apply to multiple different functions.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to the concept of limits
Finding the limit from the left and right
Different functions with the same limit
Taking the limit at different points

topics.title: Estimating limit values from tables

contents.title: Approximating limits using tables
contents.description: In this video, we learn about estimating limit values from tables. The main points are approximating the limit from the left (values less than the target) and the right (values greater than the target). By getting closer to the target value from both sides, we can estimate the limit even if the expression is not defined at the target value.

Discussion of the indeterminate form of the expression when x is equal to three
Setting up two tables to approximate the limit from the left and the right
Explanation of the difference between the limit from the left and the limit from the right
Calculating the expression for various x values to approximate the limit
Estimating the limit based on the calculations

contents.title: Estimating limits from tables
contents.description: When given a table of values for a function, we can estimate the limit at a certain point by observing the values the function approaches from both sides. The limit is the value the function converges to, even if the function's value at that point is different.

Estimating the limit of g as x approaches 5
Analyzing the table of values to understand the behavior of g
Explanation of why the limit is not the same as the function value at x=5
Drawing a possible graph of the function g

contents.title: Using tables to approximate limit values
contents.description: Tables can be a powerful tool to approximate a limit, but they need to be used wisely. Learn how to create tables in order to find a good approximation of a limit, and learn how to approximate a limit given a table of values.

contents.title: Creating tables for approximating limits
contents.description: Analyze tables to see if they are appropriate for approximating function limits.

contents.title: Estimating limits from tables
contents.description: Find limits numerically by analyzing a table of values.

contents.title: One-sided limits from tables

Estimating the limit of F as X approaches -2 from the right

topics.title: Determining limits using algebraic properties of limits: limit properties

contents.title: Limit properties
contents.description: This video introduces limit properties, which are intuitive rules that help simplify limit problems. The main properties covered are the sum, difference, product, quotient, and exponent rules. These properties allow you to break down complex limits into simpler components, making it easier to find the limit of a function.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to properties of limits
Sum rule for limits
Difference rule for limits
Product rule for limits
Constant multiple property for limits
Quotient property for limits
Exponent property for limits

contents.title: Limits of combined functions
contents.description: In this video, we learn how to find the limit of combined functions using algebraic properties of limits. The main ideas are that the limit of a product is the product of the limits, and that the limit of a quotient is the quotient of the limits, provided the denominator's limit isn't zero.

keyMoments.label: Introduction and problem statement
Using limit properties to break down the problem
Finding the limit of f of x
Finding the limit of h of x
Combining the two limits
Introduction of a new problem
Finding the limit of h of x and g of x
Explaining why the limit does not exist

contents.title: Limits of combined functions: piecewise functions
contents.description: This video demonstrates that even when individual limits of functions f(x) and g(x) don't exist, the limit of their sum or product might still exist. By analyzing left and right-hand limits, we can determine if the limit of the combined functions exists and find its value.

Explanation of how to solve the first limit problem
Solution to the first limit problem
Second limit problem
Solution to the second limit problem
Third limit problem
Solution to the third limit problem
Summary of the three limit problems

contents.title: Limits of combined functions: products and quotients
contents.description: Find limits of combinations of two functions whose graphs are given.

contents.title: Theorem for limits of composite functions
contents.description: This video focuses on finding the limit of composite functions, specifically the limit as 'x' approaches 'a' of f(g(x)). It explains that this limit equals f(limit as 'x' approaches 'a' of g(x)) if two conditions are met: the limit of g(x) exists, and f(x) is continuous at that limit.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to limits of composite functions
Conditions for the limit of a composite function to be equal to the function of the limit
Example of applying the theorem
Solution to the example

contents.title: Theorem for limits of composite functions: when conditions aren't met
contents.description: This video focuses on determining limits of composite functions using algebraic properties of limits. It explains that if the theorem for limits of composite functions doesn't apply, the limit might still exist. The video demonstrates this through examples and analyzing graphs of functions.

keyMoments.label: Introduction and first example
Explanation of why theorem doesn't apply
Alternative way to find the limit
Second example
Explanation of why theorem doesn't apply
Encouragement to find the limit on one's own

contents.title: Limits of composite functions: internal limit doesn't exist
contents.description: This video focuses on finding the limit of composite functions, even when the limit of the internal function does not exist. It demonstrates how to use right-handed and left-handed limits to determine if the composite function's limit exists by analyzing the graphs of the functions involved.

Attempt to find the limit of h(x) as x approaches -1
Realization that the limit of h(x) does not exist
Taking right-handed and left-handed limits
Finding the limit as x approaches -1 from the right
Finding the limit as x approaches -1 from the left
Conclusion that the limit of the composite function exists

contents.title: Limits of composite functions
contents.description: Find limits of a composition of two functions whose graphs are given.

topics.title: Determining limits using algebraic properties of limits: direct substitution

contents.title: Limits by direct substitution
contents.description: Sal explains how you can easily find limits of functions at points where the functions are continuous: simply plug in the x-value into the function! Later we will learn how to find limits even when the function isn't continuous.

keyMoments.label: Introduction and problem statement
Discussion of parabola and continuity
Explanation of the limit of a continuous function
Application of the limit to the problem

contents.title: Limits by direct substitution
contents.description: Find limits of functions at specific points by directly plugging the point into the function.

Evaluating the second limit

contents.title: Direct substitution with limits that don't exist
contents.description: Determine limits by direct substitution. Limits might be nonexistent.

contents.title: Limits of trigonometric functions
contents.description: This video covers limits of trigonometric functions, focusing on sine, cosine, and tangent. It emphasizes that sine and cosine are continuous and defined for all real numbers, so their limits can be found using direct substitution. For tangent and cotangent, limits depend on whether the point is in their domain.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to limits involving trigonometric functions
Finding limits for sine and cosine
General rule for limits of sine and cosine
Finding limits for tangent
Finding limits for cotangent

contents.title: Limits of piecewise functions

We learn that to find one-sided and two-sided limits, we need to consider the function definition for the specific interval we're approaching and substitute the value of x accordingly.

contents.title: Limits of piecewise functions
contents.description: Given the rules for a piecewise function, find limits of that function.

contents.title: Limits of piecewise functions: absolute value
contents.description: This video focuses on finding the limit of |x-3|/(x-3) at x=3 by rewriting it and examining it as a piecewise function. This approach helps us understand the behavior of the function for x values greater or less than 3, revealing that the limit doesn't exist.

Rewriting function f(x) for two cases: x > 3 and x < 3
Visualizing function f(x) on a graph
Determining the limit of f(x) as x approaches 3 from the left
Determining the limit of f(x) as x approaches 3 from the right
Conclusion: the limit does not exist

contents.title: Limits by factoring
contents.description: In this video, we explore the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) as x approaches 2. By factoring and simplifying the expression, we discover that the function is undefined at x = 2, but its limit from both sides as x approaches 2 is in fact 5.

Graphing the function
Finding the limit of f of x graphically
Finding the limit of f of x numerically

contents.title: Limits by rationalizing
contents.description: In this video, we explore how to find the limit of a function as x approaches -1. The function is (x+1)/(√(x+5)-2). To tackle the indeterminate form 0/0, we "rationalize the denominator" by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator. This simplifies the expression, allowing us to evaluate the limit.

keyMoments.label: Introduction and problem statement
Attempt to use limit properties
Encountering indeterminate form
Rationalizing the denominator
Simplifying the expression
Defining a new function to avoid discontinuity
Evaluating the limit

contents.title: Trig limit using Pythagorean identity
contents.description: In this video, we explore finding the limit as θ approaches 0 for the expression (1-cosθ)/(2sin²θ). By using the Pythagorean identity, we rewrite the expression to simplify it and avoid the indeterminate form 0/0. This allows us to evaluate the limit and find the answer, 1/4.

Encountering an indeterminate form
Using trigonometric identities to rewrite the expression
Factoring the expression
Defining a new function to avoid the discontinuity

We use the cosine double angle identity to rewrite the expression, allowing us to simplify and cancel terms. This approach helps us overcome the indeterminate form and find the limit, showcasing the power of trig identities in solving limit problems.

keyMoments.label: Introduction and problem statement
Attempt to solve by substitution
Encountering an indeterminate form
Using trigonometric identities to simplify
Further simplification and cancellation
Final evaluation of the limit

contents.title: Limits using trig identities
contents.description: Find limits of trigonometric functions by rewriting them using trigonometric identities.

topics.title: Selecting procedures for determining limits

contents.title: Strategy in finding limits
contents.description: In this video we explore strategies for determining which technique to use when finding limits. We also highlight the importance of understanding various methods, such as direct substitution, factoring, multiplying by conjugates, and using trig identities. By knowing when to apply each technique, we can effectively tackle different types of limit problems and enhance our problem-solving skills.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to strategies for finding limits
First strategy: substituting the value of x
Dealing with vertical asymptotes
Second strategy: factoring to simplify the expression
Third strategy: multiplying by the conjugate
Fourth strategy: using trigonometric identities
Last resort: approximation

contents.title: Strategy in finding limits
contents.description: There are many techniques for finding limits that apply in various conditions. It's important to know all these techniques, but it's also important to know when to apply which technique.

contents.title: Conclusions from direct substitution (finding limits)
contents.description: Analyze limits to see whether they can be found using direct substitution.

contents.title: Next steps after indeterminate form (finding limits)
contents.description: Analyze indeterminate limits to see which method can be used to find them.

contents.title: Strategy in finding limits
contents.description: Analyze the entire process of finding limits in any form.

topics.title: Determining limits using the squeeze theorem

contents.title: Squeeze theorem intro
contents.description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to the squeeze theorem
Analogy with calories
Mathematical explanation
Graphical representation
Application of the theorem
Utility of the theorem

contents.title: Limit of sin(x)/x as x approaches 0
contents.description: In this video, we prove that the limit of sin(θ)/θ as θ approaches 0 is equal to 1. We use a geometric construction involving a unit circle, triangles, and trigonometric functions. By comparing the areas of these triangles and applying the squeeze theorem, we demonstrate that the limit is indeed 1. This proof helps clarify a fundamental concept in calculus.

Defining the lengths of various lines in terms of trigonometric functions
Calculating the areas of various shapes
Comparing the areas to establish an inequality
Algebraic manipulation to isolate the desired expression
Applying the squeeze theorem to find the limit

contents.title: Limit of (1-cos(x))/x as x approaches 0
contents.description: In this video, we explore the limit of (1-cos(x))/x as x approaches 0 and show that it equals 0. We use the Pythagorean trigonometric identity, algebraic manipulation, and the known limit of sin(x)/x as x approaches 0 to prove this result. This concept is helpful for understanding the derivative of sin(x).

Algebraic manipulation of the expression
Using the Pythagorean trigonometric identity
Separating the expression into two limits
Simplifying the two limits
Conclusion

topics.title: Exploring types of discontinuities

contents.title: Types of discontinuities
contents.description: This video discusses three discontinuity types: point/removable, jump, and asymptotic/infinite. Point/removable occurs when the two-sided limit exists but differs from the function's value. Jump arises when one-sided limits aren't equal, and asymptotic/infinite happens when the two-sided limit is unbounded. Continuity requires the two-sided limit to match the function's value.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to discontinuities
Point or removable discontinuity
Jump discontinuity
Asymptotic discontinuity

topics.title: Defining continuity at a point

contents.title: Continuity at a point
contents.description: A function f is continuous at a point x=c if we can draw its graph at that point without lifting our pencil. To define this rigorously, f is continuous at x=c if the two-sided limit of f(x) as x approaches c exists and matches the value of f(c).

keyMoments.label: Introduction to continuity
Intuitive definition of continuity
Formal definition of continuity
Example of a continuous function
Example of a discontinuous function with a point discontinuity
Example of a discontinuous function where the two-sided limit doesn't exist

We analyze two examples to determine if the left-hand and right-hand limits exist, if the function is defined at the point, and then we use these observations to determine if the function is continuous at that point.

contents.title: Continuity at a point (graphical)

contents.description: In this video, we explore the limit of a piecewise function at the point where two cases of the function meet. By finding the left-hand and right-hand limits, we can determine if they're equal. If so, the limit exists at that point, and we've successfully analyzed the function's behavior.

topics.title: Confirming continuity over an interval

contents.title: Continuity over an interval
contents.description: A function ƒ is continuous over the open interval (a,b) if and only if it's continuous on every point in (a,b). ƒ is continuous over the closed interval [a,b] if and only if it's continuous on (a,b), the right-sided limit of ƒ at x=a is ƒ(a) and the left-sided limit of ƒ at x=b is ƒ(b).

keyMoments.label: Introduction to continuity over an interval
Definition of continuity at a point
Continuity over an open interval
Examples of continuity over an open interval
Continuity over a closed interval
Examples of continuity over a closed interval

contents.title: Functions continuous on all real numbers
contents.description: Discover how to determine if a function is continuous on all real numbers by examining two examples: eˣ and √x. Generally, common functions exhibit continuity within their domain. Explore the concept of continuity, including asymptotic and jump discontinuities, and learn how to identify continuous functions in various scenarios.

contents.title: Infinite limits and asymptotes
contents.description: Exploring unbounded limits and limits at infinity, this video delves into the relationship between vertical and horizontal asymptotes. Vertical asymptotes signify undefined limits, while horizontal asymptotes can have existing limits as x approaches infinity or negative infinity. The video highlights key differences and demonstrates how functions can cross horizontal asymptotes.

This analysis helps us understand the behavior of functions around asymptotes.

Using a calculator to create a table

Applying the properties of the cosine function to the problem
Conclusion and solution

topics.title: Connecting limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes

contents.title: Introduction to limits at infinity
contents.description: Discover the concept of limits at infinity in calculus, where functions approach a finite value as x approaches positive or negative infinity. This notation helps identify horizontal asymptotes and understand the behavior of functions as x gets larger or smaller, providing insight into the graph's structure.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to limits of functions
Discussion of limits at infinity
Examples of different functions and their limits
Summary of the notation and definition of limits at infinity

contents.title: Functions with same limit at infinity
contents.description: Exploring limits at infinity reveals that various functions can share the same limit as x approaches infinity. By examining diverse functions, including those with oscillations and natural logs, we can appreciate the infinite possibilities of functions converging to a common limit as x grows infinitely large.

Second example of a function with a limit of 3
Third example of a function with a limit of 3
Comparing the three functions
Zooming in to see the functions' behavior near the asymptote
Conclusion

contents.title: Limits at infinity: graphical
contents.description: Match expressions for limits at infinity with graphical behavior.

contents.title: Limits at infinity of quotients (Part 1)
contents.description: Discover how to determine the limits at positive and negative infinity for rational functions like (4x⁵-3x²+3)/(6x⁵-100x²-10). By focusing on the dominant terms and their growth rates, you'll learn to identify horizontal asymptotes and understand the function's behavior as x approaches infinity.

Two possible methods for solving the problem
Reasoning through the problem by examining the numerator and denominator
Explanation of why the highest degree terms are the most significant
Simplifying the equation
Verifying the solution with a graph

contents.title: Limits at infinity of quotients (Part 2)
contents.description: In this exploration of limits at infinity for rational functions, we examine three general cases of limit behavior. By identifying dominating terms and simplifying expressions, we can determine horizontal asymptotes and unbounded limits, ultimately deepening our understanding these essential calculus concepts.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to finding limits of functions
First example: function approaching infinity
Second example: function approaching negative infinity
Third example: function approaching infinity with different dominating terms

So for example,
in the numerator,

out of these three terms,
the 9x to the seventh

is going to grow much faster
than any of these other terms.

So this is the dominating
term in the numerator.

And in the denominator,
3x to the seventh

is going to grow much faster
than an x to the fifth term,

and definitely much faster
than a log base 2 term.

So at infinity, as we get
closer and closer to infinity,

this function is going
to be roughly equal to 9x

to the seventh over
3x to the seventh.

And so we can say,
especially since,

as we get larger and larger
as we get closer and closer

to infinity, these
two things are

going to get closer
and closer each other.

We could say this
limit is going to be
the same thing as this limit.

Which is going to be
equal to the limit
as x approaches infinity.

Well, we can just cancel
out the x to the seventh.

So it's going to
be 9/3, or just 3.
Which is just going to be 3.

So that is our limit, as
x approaches infinity,
in all of this craziness.

Now let's do the same with
this function over here.
Once again, crazy function.

We're going to
negative infinity.
But the same principles apply.

Which terms dominate as
the absolute value of x

get larger and
larger and larger?
As x gets larger in magnitude.

Well, in the numerator, it's
the 3x to the third term.

In the denominator it's
the 6x to the fourth term.

So this is going to be the
same thing as the limit of 3x

to the third over 6x to
the fourth, as x approaches
negative infinity.

And if we simplified
this, this is

going to be equal to the
limit as x approaches
negative infinity of 1 over 2x.
And what's this going to be?

Well, if the denominator,
even though it's

becoming a larger and larger
and larger negative number,

it becomes 1 over a very,
very large negative number.

Which is going to get us
pretty darn close to 0.

Just as 1 over x, as x
approaches negative infinity,
gets us close to 0.

So this right over here,
the horizontal asymptote

in this case, is
y is equal to 0.

And I encourage you to graph
it, or try it out with numbers
to verify that for yourself.

The key realization here
is to simplify the problem

by just thinking
about which terms
are going to dominate the rest.
Now let's think about this one.

What is the limit of
this crazy function
as x approaches infinity?

Well, once again, what
are the dominating terms?

In the numerator, it's 4x to the
fourth, and in the denominator
it's 250x to the third.

These are the
highest degree terms.

So this is going to be the
same thing as the limit,

as x approaches infinity, of
4x to the fourth over 250x
to the third.

Which is going to be the same
thing as the limit of-- let's

see, 4, well I
could just-- this is

going to be the same thing
as-- well we could divide two hundred

and, well, I'll just
leave it like this.

It's going to be the
limit of 4 over 250.

x to the fourth divided by
x to the third is just x.

Times x, as x
approaches infinity.

Or we could even say this
is going to be 4/250 times

the limit, as x
approaches infinity of x.
Now what's this?

What's the limit of x as
x approaches infinity?

Well, it's just going
to keep growing forever.

So this is just going to
be, this right over here
is just going to be infinity.

Infinity times some
number right over here
is going to be infinity.

So the limit as x approaches
infinity of all of this,
it's actually unbounded.
It's infinity.

And a kind of obvious way
of seeing that, right,

from the get go, is to
realize that the numerator has
a fourth degree term.

While the highest degree
term in the denominator
is only a third degree term.

So the numerator is
going to grow far faster
than the denominator.

So if the numerator
is growing far faster

than the denominator,
you're going

to approach infinity
in this case.

If the numerator is growing
slower than the denominator,

if the denominator is growing

like this case, you
