So hopefully you find
that a little bit useful.

contents.title: Limits at infinity of quotients
contents.description: Analyze what value a rational function approaches at infinity (if at all).

contents.title: Limits at infinity of quotients with square roots (odd power)
contents.description: Discover how to find the limits at positive and negative infinity for the function x/√(x²+1). Learn how the leading term's odd power (1) results in different limits at positive and negative infinity, and understand how this impacts horizontal asymptotes and end behavior.

keyMoments.label: Introduction of function f(x)
Considering the limit of f(x) as x approaches positive and negative infinity
Intuitive explanation of the function's behavior as x gets larger
Simplifying the function by eliminating insignificant terms
Restating the limits in terms of absolute value
Graphing the function and identifying horizontal asymptotes

subtitles.text: Let's say that f(x) is equal to x over the square root of x^2+1
and I want to think about the limit of f(x) as x approaches positive infinity
and the limit of f(x) as x approaches neagative infinity.
So let's think about what these are going to be.
Well, once again, and I'm not doing this in an ultra-rigorous way but more in an intuitive way
is to think about what this function approximately equals
as we get larger and larger and larger x'es.
This is the case if we're getting very positive x'es, in very positive infinity direction or very negative.
Still the absolute value of those x'es are very very very large as we approach positive infinity
or negative infinity.
Well, in the numerator we only have only 1 term -- we have this x term --
-- but in the denominator we have 2 terms under the radical here.
And as x gets larger and larger and larger either in the positive or the negative direction
this x squared term is going to really dominate this one
You can imagine, when x is 1 million, you're going to have a million squared plus one.
The value of the denominator is going to be dictated by this x squared term.
So this is going to be approximately equal to x over the square root of x squared.
This term right over here, the 1 isn't going to matter so much when we get very very very large x'es.
And this right over here -- x over the square root of x squared or x over the principle root of x squared --
-- this is going to be equal to x over --
-- if I square something and then take the principle root --
-- remember that the principle root is the positive square root of something --
-- then I'm essentially taking the absolute value of x.
This is going to be equal to x over the absolute value of x
for x approaches infinity or for x approaches negative infinity.
So, another way to say this, another way to restate these limits,
is as we approach infinity, this limit, we can restate it as the limit,
this is going to be equal to the limit as x approaches infinity of x over the absolute value of x.
Now, for positive x'es the absolute value of x is just going to be x.
This is going to be x divided by x, so this is just going to be 1.
Similarly, right over here, we take the limit as we go to negative infinity,
this is going to be the limit of x over the absolute value of x as x approaches negative infinity.
Remember, the only reason I was able to make this statement is that f(x) and this thing right over here
become very very similar, you can kind of say converge to each other,
as x gets very very very large or x gets very very very very negative.
Now, for negative values of x the absolute value of x is going to be positive,
x is obviously going to be negative and we're just going to get negative 1.
And so using this, we can actually try to graph our function.
So let's try to do that.
So let's say, that is my y axis,
this is my x axis,
and we see that we have 2 horizontal asymptotes.
We have 1 horizontal asymptote at y=1,
so let's say this right over here is y=1,
let me draw that line as dotted line,
we're going to approach this thing,
and then we have another horizontal asymptote at y=-1.
So that might be right over there, y=-1.
And if we want to plot at least 1 point we can think about what does f(0) equal.
So, f(0) is going to be equal to 0 over the square root of 0+1, or 0 squared plus 1.
Well that's all just going to be equal to zero.
So we have this point, right over here,
and we know that as x approaches infinity, we're approaching this blue, horizontal asymptote,
so it might look something like this.
Let me do it a little bit differently. There you go.
I'll clean this up. So it might look something like this.
That's not the color I wanted to use.
So it might look something like that.
We get closer and closer to that asymptote as x gets larger and larger
and then like this -- we get closer and closer to this asymptote as x approaches negative infinity.
I'm not drawing it so well.
So that right over there is y=f(x).
And you can verify this by taking a calculator, trying to plot more points
or using some type of graphing calculator or something.
But anyway, I just wanted to tackle another situation we're approaching infinity and or negative infinity
and we're trying to determine the horizontal asymptotes.
And remember, the key is just to say what terms dominate
as x approaches positive infinity or negative infinity.
To say, well, what is that function going to approach, and it's going to approach this horizontal asymptote
in the positive direction and this one in the negative.

contents.title: Limits at infinity of quotients with square roots (even power)
contents.description: Discover how to find the limit at infinity of rational expressions with radicals by dividing the numerator and denominator by the highest degree term. Mastering this technique will help us to analyze end behavior and to evaluate other limits involving infinity.

contents.title: Limits at infinity of quotients with square roots
contents.description: Find limits at infinity of rational functions with a radical expression in the numerator or denominator.

topics.title: Limits and continuity: Quiz 5
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Working with the intermediate value theorem

contents.title: Intermediate value theorem
contents.description: Discover the Intermediate Value Theorem, a fundamental concept in calculus that states if a function is continuous over a closed interval [a, b], it encompasses every value between f(a) and f(b) within that range. Dive into this foundational theorem and explore its connection to continuous functions and their behavior on intervals.

contents.title: Worked example: using the intermediate value theorem
contents.description: Discover how the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees specific outcomes for continuous functions. With a given function f, where f(-2) = 3 and f(1) = 6, learn to identify the correct statement that aligns with the theorem's principles and understand its real-life applications.

contents.title: Using the intermediate value theorem
contents.description: Use the Intermediate value theorem to solve some problems.

contents.title: Justification with the intermediate value theorem: table
contents.description: Discover how to apply the Intermediate Value Theorem with a table-defined function. Learn to determine if a continuous function has a solution within a specified interval, and justify your reasoning using the theorem's principles. Explore real-life applications and enhance your understanding of calculus concepts.

contents.title: Justification with the intermediate value theorem: equation
contents.description: Discover how to apply the Intermediate Value Theorem to determine if a function has a solution within a specific interval. This engaging lesson explores the theorem's conditions, continuity, and justification using real-world examples and equations. Master the art of working with rational functions and their domains to enhance your calculus skills.

contents.title: Justification with the intermediate value theorem
contents.description: Given a table of values of a function, determine which conditions allow us to make certain conclusions based on the Intermediate Value Theorem or the Extreme Value Theorem.

contents.title: Intermediate value theorem review
contents.description: Review the intermediate value theorem and use it to solve problems.

topics.title: Limits and continuity: Quiz 6
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Optional videos

contents.title: Formal definition of limits Part 1: intuition review
contents.description: Discover the essence of limits in calculus as we prepare to dive into the formal definition. Enhance your understanding of this fundamental concept by reviewing how function values approach a specific limit as the input variable gets closer to a certain point. Get ready to explore the mathematical rigor behind limits!

contents.title: Formal definition of limits Part 2: building the idea
contents.description: Explore the rigorous mathematical definition of a limit as x approaches c, and understand how to get f(x) as close to L as desired by finding a range around c. Dive into the epsilon-delta definition and its application in proving limits for various functions.

contents.title: Formal definition of limits Part 3: the definition
contents.description: Explore the epsilon-delta definition of limits, which states that the limit of f(x) at x=c equals L if, for any ε>0, there's a δ>0 ensuring that when the distance between x and c is less than δ, the distance between f(x) and L is less than ε. This concept captures the idea of getting arbitrarily close to L.

contents.title: Formal definition of limits Part 4: using the definition
contents.description: Explore the epsilon-delta definition of limits in calculus, as we rigorously prove a limit exists for a piecewise function. Dive into the process of defining delta as a function of epsilon, and learn how to apply this concept to validate limits with precision.

topics.title: Limits and continuity: Unit test
topics.description: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

units.title: Differentiation: definition and basic derivative rules
units.description: The derivative of a function describes the function's instantaneous rate of change at a certain point - it gives us the slope of the line tangent to the function's graph at that point. See how we define the derivative using limits, and learn to find derivatives quickly with the very useful power, product, and quotient rules.

topics.title: Defining average and instantaneous rates of change at a point

contents.title: Newton, Leibniz, and Usain Bolt
contents.description: Why do we study differential calculus? Dive into the core concepts of instantaneous rates of change and their practical applications. Uncover the connection between Newton and Leibniz's pioneering work and Usain Bolt's impressive sprinting speeds, while grasping the significance of determining instantaneous velocity in diverse situations.

contents.title: Derivative as a concept
contents.description: Learn about derivatives as the instantaneous rate of change and the slope of the tangent line. This video introduces key concepts, including the difference between average and instantaneous rates of change, and how derivatives are central to differential calculus. Master various notations used to represent derivatives, such as Leibniz's, Lagrange's, and Newton's notations.

contents.title: Secant lines & average rate of change
contents.description: Learn how to calculate the average rate of change for a function and its connection to the slope of a secant line. Grasp the concept of instantaneous rate of change and its significance in calculus, leading to the idea of the derivative.

contents.title: Secant lines & average rate of change
contents.description: Find the average rate of change of a function, or the slope of a secant line to the graph of the function.

contents.title: Derivative notation review
contents.description: Review the different common ways of writing derivatives.

contents.title: Derivative as slope of curve
contents.description: Explore how to interpret the derivative of a function at a specific point as the curve's slope or the tangent line's slope at that point. Dive into problem-solving examples that demonstrate this concept and strengthen your understanding of derivatives in calculus.

contents.title: Derivative as slope of curve
contents.description: Practice your intuitive understanding of the derivative at a point as the slope of the curve (or of the tangent to the curve) at that point.

contents.title: The derivative & tangent line equations
contents.description: Discover how the derivative of a function reveals the slope of the tangent line at any point on the graph. We'll explore how to use this powerful tool to determine the equation of the tangent line, enhancing our understanding of instantaneous rates of change.

contents.title: The derivative & tangent line equations
contents.description: Analyze derivatives of functions at specific points as the slope of the lines tangent to the functions' graphs at those points.

topics.title: Defining the derivative of a function and using derivative notation

contents.title: Formal definition of the derivative as a limit
contents.description: Discover how to define the derivative of a function at a specific point using the limit of the slope of the secant line. We'll explore the concept of finding the slope as the difference in function values approaches zero, represented by the limit of [f(c)-f(c+h)]/h as h→0.

contents.title: Formal and alternate form of the derivative
contents.description: Discover the two methods for defining the derivative of a function at a specific point using limit expressions. In this video we'll explore the standard form and alternate form, enhancing our understanding of tangent line slopes and secant line approximations.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative as a limit
contents.description: Discover how to apply the formal and alternate forms of the derivative in real-world scenarios. We'll explore the process of finding the slope of tangent lines using both methods and compare their effectiveness in solving calculus problems. Let's dive into the practical side of derivatives to deepen our understanding.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative from limit expression
contents.description: We explore a limit expression and discover that it represents the derivative of the function f(x) = x³ at the point x = 5. By analyzing the alternate form of the derivative, we gain a deeper understanding of tangent lines and their slopes.

contents.title: Derivative as a limit
contents.description: Write derivatives of functions as limit expressions.

contents.title: The derivative of x² at x=3 using the formal definition
contents.description: Discover how to find the derivative of x² at x=3 using the formal definition of a derivative. Learn to calculate the slope of the tangent line at a specific point on the curve y=x² by applying the limit as the change in x approaches zero. This method helps determine the instantaneous rate of change for the function.

contents.title: The derivative of x² at any point using the formal definition
contents.description: Let's find the derivative of x² at any point using the formal definition of a derivative. We will learn to apply the limit as h approaches 0 to determine the slope of the tangent line at a given point on the curve y = x². This powerful concept leads to a general formula for the derivative: f'(x) = 2x.

contents.title: Finding tangent line equations using the formal definition of a limit
contents.description: This structured practice takes you through three examples of finding the equation of the line tangent to a curve at a specific point.

topics.title: Estimating derivatives of a function at a point

contents.title: Estimating derivatives
contents.description: Let's explore how to estimate the derivative of a function at a specific point using the slope of a secant line connecting nearby points. By finding the average rate of change between these points, we can make our best guess for the instantaneous rate of change at the desired point.

contents.title: Estimate derivatives
contents.description: Given a table of values of a function, find the best estimate for the derivative of a function at a given point.

topics.title: Connecting differentiability and continuity: determining when derivatives do and do not exist

contents.title: Differentiability and continuity
contents.description: We explore the notion of differentiability at a point and its relationship with continuity, using the definition of a derivative. If a function is differentiable at x = c, then it is continuous at x = c. However, a function being continuous does not guarantee that it is differentiable, as demonstrated with an absolute value function.

contents.title: Differentiability at a point: graphical
contents.description: Let's dive into examples of functions and their graphs, focusing on finding points where the function isn't differentiable. By examining various cases such as vertical tangents, discontinuities, and sharp turns, we gain a deeper understanding of the conditions that make a function non-differentiable. We then determine the x-values where the derivative doesn't exist, further solidifying our knowledge of differentiability.

contents.title: Differentiability at a point: graphical
contents.description: Analyze graphs of functions to determine where they are not differentiable.

contents.title: Differentiability at a point: algebraic (function is differentiable)
contents.description: We examine a piecewise function to determine its continuity and differentiability at an edge point. By analyzing left and right hand limits, we establish continuity. Checking the limit of the difference quotient confirms both left and right hand limits are equal, making the function continuous and differentiable at the edge point.

contents.title: Differentiability at a point: algebraic (function isn't differentiable)
contents.description: We examine a piecewise function to determine its differentiability and continuity at an edge point. Through analyzing left and right-hand limits, we find that the function is continuous at the point. However, due to differing slopes from the left and right, the function is not differentiable at the edge point.

contents.title: Differentiability at a point: algebraic
contents.description: Analyze algebraic functions to determine whether they are continuous and/or differentiable at a given point.

topics.title: Differentiation: definition and basic derivative rules: Quiz 1
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Applying the power rule

contents.title: Power rule
contents.description: Let's dive into the power rule, a handy tool for finding the derivative of xⁿ. This rule simplifies the process of taking derivatives, especially for polynomials, by bringing the exponent out front and decrementing the power. We explore examples with positive, negative, and fractional exponents.

contents.title: Power rule (positive integer powers)
contents.description: Use the power rule to differentiate functions of the form xⁿ where n is a positive integer.

contents.title: Power rule (negative & fractional powers)
contents.description: Use the power rule to differentiate functions of the form xⁿ where n is a negative integer or a fraction.

contents.title: Power rule (with rewriting the expression)
contents.description: Discover how the power rule helps us find derivatives of functions like 1/x, ∛x, or ∛x². By rewriting these functions as xⁿ, where n is a negative or fractional exponent, we can apply the power rule to calculate their derivatives with ease.

contents.title: Power rule (with rewriting the expression)
contents.description: Find and evaluate the derivatives of expressions like ∜x³  and 1/x² by rewriting them in the form xⁿ and using the power rule.

contents.title: Justifying the power rule
contents.description: ​Proving the power rule for derivatives (only the more simple cases).

topics.title: Derivative rules: constant, sum, difference, and constant multiple: introduction

contents.title: Basic derivative rules
contents.description: Let's explore how to find the derivative of any polynomial using the power rule and additional properties. The derivative of a constant is always 0, and we can pull out a scalar constant when taking the derivative. Furthermore, the derivative of a sum of two functions is simply the sum of their derivatives.

contents.title: Basic derivative rules: find the error
contents.description: We analyze two students' attempts to differentiate linear functions using basic rules. One student forgets a negative sign, while another incorrectly assumes the derivative of a product equals the product of derivatives. By identifying common mistakes, we help improve our understanding of differentiation.

contents.title: Basic derivative rules: find the error
contents.description: Analyze solutions for finding the derivatives of linear functions using basic differentiation rules.

contents.title: Basic derivative rules: table
contents.description: Let's explore a problem involving two functions, f and g, and their derivatives at specific points. Our goal is to find the derivative of a new function, h(x), which is a combination of these functions: 3f(x)+2g(x). By applying basic derivative rules, we determine the derivative—and thus the slope of the tangent line—of h(x) at x = 9.

contents.title: Basic derivative rules: table
contents.description: Use basic differentiation rules to evaluate derivatives of combined functions.

topics.title: Derivative rules: constant, sum, difference, and constant multiple: connecting with the power rule

contents.title: Differentiating polynomials
contents.description: Let's explore how to differentiate polynomials using the power rule and derivative properties. We work with the function f(x)=x⁵+2x³-x² and apply the power rule to find its derivative, f'(x)=5x⁴+6x²-2x. Next, we evaluate f'(x) at x=2, determining that f'(2)=100, which represents the rate of change or slope of the tangent line at the specified point.

contents.title: Differentiate polynomials
contents.description: Find and evaluate derivatives of polynomials.

contents.title: Differentiating integer powers (mixed positive and negative)
contents.description: Let's explore how to differentiate the function g(x) = 2/(x³) - 1/(x²) and evaluate the derivative at x = 2. By applying the Power Rule and simplifying, we efficiently find the slope of the tangent line at the given point.

contents.title: Differentiate integer powers (mixed positive and negative)
contents.description: Find and evaluate the derivatives of functions with multiple terms using power, constant, sum, difference, and constant multiple rules.

contents.title: Tangents of polynomials
contents.description: Let's explore the process of finding the equation of the tangent line to the graph of f(x) = x³ - 6x² + x - 5 at x = 1. By calculating the derivative and evaluating it at x = 1, we determine the slope and use point-slope form to obtain the tangent line equation.

contents.title: Tangents of polynomials
contents.description: Find equations of tangent lines to polynomial functions at a given point.

topics.title: Differentiation: definition and basic derivative rules: Quiz 2
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Derivatives of cos(x), sin(x), 𝑒ˣ, and ln(x)

contents.title: Derivatives of sin(x) and cos(x)
contents.description: Now we explore the intuition behind the derivatives of trigonometric functions, discovering that the derivative of sin(x) is cos(x) and the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x). By analyzing tangent line slopes, we gain a deeper understanding of these fundamental relationships.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivatives of sin(x) and cos(x)
contents.description: Dive into the derivative of the function g(x) = 7sin(x) - 3cos(x) - (π/∛x)². By applying the power rule and the derivatives of sine and cosine functions, we efficiently determine the derivative g'(x) = 7cos(x) + 3sin(x) + 2π²/3 * x^(-5/3). Through algebraic manipulation and careful attention to detail, we tackle the problem's initially intimidating appearance.

contents.title: Derivatives of sin(x) and cos(x)
contents.description: Find the derivatives of functions that contain sin(x) or cos(x). For example, differentiate f(x)=2x+3sin(x).

contents.title: Proving the derivatives of sin(x) and cos(x)
contents.description: ​Proving that the derivative of sin(x) is cos(x) and that the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x).

contents.title: Derivative of 𝑒ˣ
contents.description: Discover the fascinating property of the derivative of 𝑒ˣ, which remains 𝑒ˣ after differentiation. This unique characteristic is central to our understanding and exploration of exponential functions, showcasing the remarkable nature of the number 𝑒.

contents.title: Derivative of ln(x)
contents.description: Let's explore the concept that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x by examining the slopes of tangent lines at various points on the graph of y=ln(x). We'll observe that the slopes match the values of 1/x, reinforcing the statement. A future video will provide a proof for this concept.

contents.title: Derivatives of 𝑒ˣ and ln(x)
contents.description: Use your knowledge of the derivatives of 𝑒ˣ and ln(x) to solve problems.

contents.title: Proof: The derivative of 𝑒ˣ is 𝑒ˣ
Proof: the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x

topics.title: The product rule

contents.title: Product rule
contents.description: Discover the product rule, a fundamental technique for finding the derivative of a function expressed as a product of two functions. We'll learn how to apply this rule to simplify differentiation and enhance our understanding of calculus.

contents.title: Differentiating products
contents.description: We explore the product rule by finding the derivative of eˣcos(x). We identify eˣ as the first function and cos(x) as the second, then apply the product rule to calculate the derivative, simplifying our result for a clearer understanding.

contents.title: Differentiate products
contents.description: Find the derivatives of products of basic functions.

contents.title: Worked example: Product rule with table
contents.description: We explore how to evaluate the derivative of the product of two functions, f(x) and h(x), at x=3, using given values for f, h, and their derivatives. Applying the product rule, we calculate the derivative of f(x)⋅h(x) at x=3 with ease.

contents.title: Worked example: Product rule with mixed implicit & explicit
contents.description: We explore how to calculate the derivative of F(x) = f(x)⋅g(x) at x = -1, given the values of f and f' at x = -1 and g(x) = 1/x. By applying the product rule, we efficiently determine F'(x) and evaluate it at the specified point.

contents.title: Product rule with tables
contents.description: Practice applying the product rule.

contents.title: Proving the product rule
contents.description: Proving the product rule for derivatives.

contents.title: Product rule review
contents.description: Review your knowledge of the Product rule for derivatives, and use it to solve problems.

topics.title: The quotient rule

contents.title: Quotient rule
contents.description: Discover the quotient rule, a powerful technique for finding the derivative of a function expressed as a quotient. We'll explore how to apply this rule by differentiating the numerator and denominator functions, and then combining them to simplify the result.

contents.title: Differentiate quotients
contents.description: Find the derivatives of quotients of basic functions.

contents.title: Worked example: Quotient rule with table
contents.description: Let's explore how to find the derivative of F(x) = f(x)/g(x) at x = -1, given the values of f and f' at x = -1 and g(x) = 2x³. By applying the quotient rule, we efficiently calculate the derivative, F'(x), and evaluate it at the specified point.

contents.title: Quotient rule with tables
contents.description: Practice applying the quotient rule.

contents.title: Differentiating rational functions
contents.description: Let's dive into the differentiation of the rational function (5-3x)/(x²+3x) using the Quotient Rule. By identifying the numerator and denominator as separate functions, we apply the Quotient Rule to find the derivative, simplifying the expression for a clear understanding of the process. This approach can be applied to differentiate any other rational function as well.

contents.title: Differentiate rational functions
contents.description: Find and evaluate derivatives of rational functions.

contents.title: Quotient rule review
contents.description: Review your knowledge of the Quotient rule for derivatives, and use it to solve problems.

topics.title: Finding the derivatives of tangent, cotangent, secant, and/or cosecant functions

contents.title: Derivatives of tan(x) and cot(x)
contents.description: We find the derivatives of tan(x) and cot(x) by rewriting them as quotients of sin(x) and cos(x). Using the quotient rule, we determine that the derivative of tan(x) is sec^2(x) and the derivative of cot(x) is -csc^2(x). This process involves applying the Pythagorean identity to simplify final results.

contents.title: Derivatives of sec(x) and csc(x)
contents.description: Let's explore the derivatives of sec(x) and csc(x) by expressing them as 1/cos(x) and 1/sin(x), respectively, and applying the quotient rule. We discover that the derivative of sec(x) can be written as sin(x)/cos²(x) or tan(x)sec(x), and the derivative of csc(x) can be expressed as -cos(x)/sin²(x) or -cot(x)csc(x).

contents.title: Derivatives of tan(x), cot(x), sec(x), and csc(x)
contents.description: Find and evaluate derivatives of tangent, cotangent, secant, & cosecant.

topics.title: Differentiation: definition and basic derivative rules: Quiz 3
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Optional videos

contents.title: Proof: Differentiability implies continuity
contents.description: We explore the connection between differentiability and continuity, demonstrating that if a function is differentiable at a point, it must also be continuous at that point. By examining the properties of limits and using algebra, we prove this relationship for a function at a given point.

contents.title: Justifying the power rule
contents.description: Let's explore the power rule's validity by examining the derivatives of x¹ and x². We'll analyze the slopes of tangent lines for these functions and then see how the power rule provides reasonable results, building our confidence in its usefulness.

contents.title: Proof of power rule for positive integer powers
contents.description: We dive into proving the formula for the derivative of x^n by skillfully applying the binomial theorem. Together, we expand (x + Δx)^n, simplify the expression, and take the limit as Δx approaches zero to reveal the power rule for derivatives.

contents.title: Proof of power rule for square root function
contents.description: We explore a proof of the power rule for the special case when n=½, focusing on the derivative of √x. By applying the definition of a derivative and utilizing the conjugate, we demonstrate that the power rule holds true for this specific case.

contents.title: Limit of sin(x)/x as x approaches 0
contents.description: In this video, we prove that the limit of sin(θ)/θ as θ approaches 0 is equal to 1. We use a geometric construction involving a unit circle, triangles, and trigonometric functions. By comparing the areas of these triangles and applying the squeeze theorem, we demonstrate that the limit is indeed 1. This proof helps clarify a fundamental concept in calculus.

contents.title: Limit of (1-cos(x))/x as x approaches 0
contents.description: In this video, we explore the limit of (1-cos(x))/x as x approaches 0 and show that it equals 0. We use the Pythagorean trigonometric identity, algebraic manipulation, and the known limit of sin(x)/x as x approaches 0 to prove this result. This concept is helpful for understanding the derivative of sin(x).

contents.title: Proof of the derivative of sin(x)
contents.description: Let's dive into the proof that the derivative of sin(x) equals cos(x). By applying angle addition formulas, the squeeze theorem, and exploring the concept of limits, we unravel this interesting proof. This exploration not only solidifies our understanding, but also equips us to handle more complex derivatives in the future.

contents.title: Proof of the derivative of cos(x)
contents.description: Let's leverage our understanding that the derivative of sin(x) equals cos(x) to visually demonstrate that the derivative of cos(x) equals -sin(x). By strategically shifting graphs and applying trigonometric identities, we'll establish a strong visual argument, deepening our comprehension of these key calculus concepts.

contents.title: Product rule proof
contents.description: Let's delve into the proof of the product rule, a key concept in calculus. We apply the definition of a derivative to the product of two functions, making sense of this rule. Through smart algebraic manipulation, we arrive at the classic product rule formula.

topics.title: Differentiation: definition and basic derivative rules: Unit test
topics.description: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

units.title: Differentiation: composite, implicit, and inverse functions
units.description: The chain rule tells us how to find the derivative of a composite function. This is an exceptionally useful rule, as it opens up a whole world of functions (and equations!) we can now differentiate. Also learn how to use all the different derivative rules together in a thoughtful and strategic manner.

topics.title: The chain rule: introduction

contents.title: Chain rule
contents.description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words, it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example, sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x², we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

contents.title: Common chain rule misunderstandings
contents.description: We tackle common misconceptions about the Chain Rule, ensuring we distinguish between product and composition of functions. We also emphasize the importance of fully applying the Chain Rule, and avoid the pitfall of taking the derivative of the outer function with respect to the derivative of the inner function.

contents.title: Chain rule
contents.description: The chain rule tells us how to find the derivative of a composite function. Brush up on your knowledge of composite functions, and learn how to apply the chain rule correctly.

contents.title: Identifying composite functions
contents.description: Now let's explore the world of composite functions, honing our skills at recognizing them in various forms. This understanding is crucial to get the most out of the Chain Rule. We'll explore how functions can be composed, and even how they can be expressed as products, setting a strong foundation for advanced calculus concepts.

contents.title: Identify composite functions
contents.description: Given a function, determine whether it's a composite function. If so, determine the "inner" and "outer" functions.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative of cos³(x) using the chain rule
contents.description: Now let's tackle a worked example of composite functions, using the example f(x) = cos³(x). By applying the chain rule, we differentiate this function, breaking it down into its components x³ and cos(x). This helps us understand how to handle other complex derivatives with ease.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative of √(3x²-x) using the chain rule
contents.description: Let's dive into the process of differentiating a composite function, specifically f(x)=sqrt(3x^2-x), using the chain rule. By breaking down the function into its components, sqrt(x) and 3x^2-x, we demonstrate how their derivatives work together to make differentiation easier.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative of ln(√x) using the chain rule
contents.description: In this worked example, we dissect the composite function f(x)=ln(√x) into its parts, ln(x) and √x. By applying the chain rule, we successfully differentiate this function, providing a clear step-by-step process for finding the derivative of similar composite functions.

contents.title: Chain rule intro
contents.description: Use the chain rule to differentiate composite functions like sin(2x+1) or [cos(x)]³.

topics.title: The chain rule: further practice

contents.title: Worked example: Chain rule with table
contents.description: Through a worked example, we explore the Chain rule with a table. Using specific x-values for functions f and g, and their derivatives, we collaboratively evaluate the derivative of a composite function F(x) = f(g(x)). By applying the chain rule, we illuminate the process, making it easy to understand.

contents.title: Chain rule with tables
contents.description: Practice applying the chain rule.

contents.title: Derivative of aˣ (for any positive base a)
contents.description: Let's dive deeper into the fascinating world of derivatives, specifically focusing on the derivative of aˣ for any positive base a. Using the derivative of eˣ and the chain rule, we unravel the mystery behind differentiating exponential functions. We then apply our newfound knowledge to differentiate the expression 8⋅3ˣ.

contents.title: Derivative of logₐx (for any positive base a≠1)
contents.description: Now let's look into the fascinating world of logarithms, exploring how to find the derivative of logₐx for any positive base a≠1. Leveraging the derivative of ln(x) and the change of base rule, we successfully differentiate log₇x and -3log_π(x). Join us on this mathematical journey!

contents.title: Derivatives of aˣ and logₐx
contents.description: Find the derivatives of simple exponential functions. For example, differentiate f(x)=3⋅2ˣ.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative of 7^(x²-x) using the chain rule
contents.description: In this worked example we explore the process of differentiating the exponential function 7^(x²-x). We Leverage our previous understanding of the derivative of aˣ and the chain rule to unravel the complexities of this composite function to find its derivative.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative of log₄(x²+x) using the chain rule
contents.description: Let's explore a worked example of differentiating the logarithmic function log₄(x²+x) using the chain rule. Leveraging our understanding of the derivative of logₐ(x), we simplify the complexities of composite functions, making differentiation more approachable and fun!

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative of sec(3π/2-x) using the chain rule
contents.description: We explore the fascinating process of differentiating the function sec(3π/2-x) in this worked example. Using the chain rule and trigonometric identities, we calculate the derivative and evaluate it at x=π/4. This problem illuminates the beauty of composite functions and their derivatives.

contents.title: Worked example: Derivative of ∜(x³+4x²+7) using the chain rule
contents.description: Let's tackle the challenge of differentiating the fourth root of a polynomial expression in this worked example. Using the chain rule and the power rule, we simplify the complex function and evaluate the derivative at x=-3. Join us on this mathematical journey!

contents.title: Chain rule capstone
contents.description: Find the derivatives of exponential, logarithmic, trigonometric, and radical functions, whose inner function is a polynomial.

contents.title: Proving the chain rule
contents.description: Proving the chain rule for derivatives.

contents.title: Derivative rules review
contents.description: Review all the common derivative rules (including Power, Product, and Chain rules).

topics.title: Differentiation: composite, implicit, and inverse functions: Quiz 1
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Implicit differentiation

contents.title: Implicit differentiation
contents.description: Some relationships cannot be represented by an explicit function. For example, x²+y²=1. Implicit differentiation helps us find ​dy/dx even for relationships like that. This is done using the chain ​rule, and viewing y as an implicit function of x. For example, according to the chain rule, the derivative of y² would be 2y⋅(dy/dx).

contents.title: Worked example: Implicit differentiation
contents.description: Using implicit differentiation, let's take on the challenge of the equation (x-y)² = x + y - 1 in this worked example. We utilize the chain rule and algebraic techniques to find the derivative of y with respect to x. This adventure deepens our grasp of how variables interact within intricate equations.

contents.title: Worked example: Evaluating derivative with implicit differentiation
contents.description: Uncover the process of calculating the slope of a tangent line at a specific point on a curve using implicit differentiation. We navigate through the steps of finding the derivative, substituting values, and simplifying to reveal the slope at x=1 for the curve x²+(y-x)³=28.

contents.title: Implicit differentiation
contents.description: Practice using implicit differentiation.

contents.title: Showing explicit and implicit differentiation give same result
contents.description: Discover the fascinating connection between implicit and explicit differentiation! In this video we'll explore a simple equation, unravel it using both methods, and find that they both lead us to the same derivative. This engaging journey demonstrates the versatility and consistency of calculus.

contents.title: Implicit differentiation review
contents.description: Review your implicit differentiation skills and use them to solve problems.

topics.title: Differentiating inverse functions

contents.title: Derivatives of inverse functions
contents.description: Explore the intriguing connection between inverse functions and their derivatives. We delve into the unique relationship that exists when f(g(x))=x=g(f(x)), using the functions 𝑒ˣ and ln(x) as examples. Uncover how this principle can help us understand the derivatives of these inverses in a new light.

contents.title: Derivatives of inverse functions: from equation
contents.description: Let's explore the intriguing relationship between a function and its inverse, focusing on the function f(x)=½x³+3x-4. We delve into the derivative of the inverse of f, applying the chain rule and the power rule to evaluate it at x=-14. Join us as we unravel this complex calculus concept.

contents.title: Derivatives of inverse functions: from table
contents.description: Let's delve into the fascinating realm of inverse functions, exploring how to evaluate the derivative of an inverse function, h', at a specific x-value. Using a provided table of values for function g, its inverse h, and its derivative g', we unravel the mystery of h' using the chain rule and the concept of inverse functions.

contents.title: Derivatives of inverse functions
contents.description: Practice the relationship between the derivatives of inverse functions:  if f and g are inverse functions, then f’(x)=1/(g’(f(x)).

topics.title: Differentiating inverse trigonometric functions

contents.title: Derivative of inverse sine
contents.description: Unlock the mystery of the derivative of inverse sine! Let's dive into the world of calculus, rearranging equations and applying implicit differentiation to find the derivative of y with respect to x. Using trigonometric identities, we transform the derivative into a function of x, revealing a fascinating relationship.

contents.title: Derivative of inverse cosine
contents.description: Unraveling the mystery of the inverse cosine function, we find its derivative equals -1/(sqrt(1 - x^2)). This step-by-step proof guides us to a fascinating comparison with the derivative of inverse sine, revealing a captivating connection between these two trigonometric functions.

contents.title: Derivative of inverse tangent
contents.description: Now let's explore the derivative of the inverse tangent function. Starting with the derivative of tangent, we use the chain rule and trigonometric identities to find the derivative of its inverse. Join us as we investigate this fascinating mathematical process!

contents.title: Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions
contents.description: Differentiate functions that contain the inverse trigonometric functions arcsin(x), arccos(x), and arctan(x).

contents.title: Differentiating inverse trig functions review
contents.description: Review the derivatives of the inverse trigonometric functions: arcsin(x), arccos(x), and arctan(x).

topics.title: Selecting procedures for calculating derivatives: strategy

contents.title: Differentiating functions: Find the error
contents.description: Let's delve into the process of differentiating functions, analyzing student work for potential errors. Our focus is on the correct application of the product, chain, and quotient rules. This exploration underscores the crucial role these rules play in calculus, enhancing our grasp of differentiation.

contents.title: Manipulating functions before differentiation
contents.description: Let's explore how manipulating functions before differentiating can make our calculus journey smoother and quicker. By tweaking our functions a bit, we can make differentiation less complex. We'll walk through several examples, showing how a touch of algebra can go a long way!

contents.title: Strategy in differentiating functions
contents.description: Differentiation has so many different rules and there are so many different ways to apply them! Let's take a broader look at differentiation and come up with a workflow that will allow us to find the derivative of any function, efficiently and without mistakes.

contents.title: Differentiating functions: Find the error
contents.description: Analyze the work of other students trying to differentiate functions to determine whether it's correct, and if not, for what reason.

contents.title: Manipulating functions before differentiation
contents.description: Analyze how various functions can be rewritten so we can apply different differentiation rules on them.

topics.title: Selecting procedures for calculating derivatives: multiple rules

contents.title: Differentiating using multiple rules: strategy
contents.description: Let's explore how to break down complex expressions and determine the right derivative rules to apply. We'll learn how to identify the structure of these expressions and decide the order of operations, using the chain rule and product rule. This strategy will help us tackle even the most elaborate expressions with confidence.

contents.title: Differentiating using multiple rules: strategy
contents.description: Strategize about how you would approach differentiating an elaborate function using either the product rule, or the quotient rule, or the chain rule.

contents.title: Applying the chain rule and product rule
contents.description: Let's explore multiple strategies to tackle derivatives involving both the product and chain rules. We start by applying the chain rule first, then the product rule. Next, we switch it up, using the product rule first, then the chain rule. Discover how these different approaches lead us to the same answer, demonstrating the flexibility and interconnectedness of these mathematical rules.

contents.title: Applying the chain rule twice
contents.description: Unravel the intricacies of applying the chain rule twice in a single problem. We'll dissect the process of finding the derivative of a function like sin(x^2)^3, demonstrating the power and adaptability of the chain rule when used not just once, but twice!

contents.title: Derivative of eᶜᵒˢˣ⋅cos(eˣ)
contents.description: By applying both the product and chain rule, we tackle the task of differentiating the function eᶜᵒˢˣ⋅cos(eˣ). This exercise not only provides us with a solution to this complex problem, but also deepens our understanding of these fundamental calculus techniques, reinforcing the importance of these rules in the broader context of calculus.

contents.title: Derivative of sin(ln(x²))
contents.description: We apply the chain rule twice to differentiate sin(ln(x²)), breaking down this composite function into simpler elements. This double application allows us to handle the complexity of the function, turning it into manageable parts. Together, we'll tackle this mathematical task with precision and clarity.

contents.title: Differentiating using multiple rules
contents.description: You think you know how to differentiate any kind of function? Try this capstone exercise.

topics.title: Differentiation: composite, implicit, and inverse functions: Quiz 2
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Calculating higher-order derivatives

contents.title: Second derivatives
contents.description: We dive into the fascinating realm of second derivatives, starting with the function y=6/x². Together, we apply the power rule to find the first derivative, then repeat the process to reveal the second derivative. This journey illuminates how we can use mathematical tools to uncover deeper layers of a function's behavior.

contents.title: Second derivatives
contents.description: Find second derivatives of various functions. For example, given f(x)=sin(2x), find f''(x).

contents.title: Second derivatives (implicit equations): find expression
contents.description: Let's explore the process of determining the second derivative of y with respect to x from an implicit equation. Using implicit differentiation, we apply the chain rule and quotient rule. This leads us to a simplified expression for the second derivative in terms of x and y.

contents.title: Second derivatives (implicit equations): evaluate derivative
contents.description: We tackle the challenge of implicit differentiation, using an equation in x and y to find the first derivative. Then, we step it up a notch by evaluating the second derivative at a specific point. All this is based on a problem from the 2015 AP Calculus AB exam.

contents.title: Second derivatives (implicit equations)
contents.description: Find second derivatives of functions that are defined through an implicit equation.

contents.title: Second derivatives review
contents.description: Review your knowledge of second derivatives.

topics.title: Further practice connecting derivatives and limits

contents.title: Disguised derivatives
contents.description: We tackle a complex limit expression, viewing it as 5 times the derivative of log(x) when x=2. This perspective enables us to evaluate the limit using differentiation rules, providing a simpler alternative to direct limit analysis. Together, let's navigate this challenging problem.

contents.title: Disguised derivatives
contents.description: Evaluate limit expressions that describe derivatives of functions.

topics.title: Differentiation: composite, implicit, and inverse functions: Quiz 3
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Optional videos

contents.title: Proof: Differentiability implies continuity
contents.description: We explore the connection between differentiability and continuity, demonstrating that if a function is differentiable at a point, it must also be continuous at that point. By examining the properties of limits and using algebra, we prove this relationship for a function at a given point.

contents.title: If function u is continuous at x, then Δu→0 as Δx→0
contents.description: Let's explore the fascinating relationship between changes in function values and x-values. When we have a continuous function, we discover that as the change in x-values (Δx) nears zero, the change in the function's values (Δu) also tends towards zero. This insight offers us a unique way to understand continuity.

contents.title: Chain rule proof
contents.description: Let's explore the proof of the chain rule, using the formal properties of continuity and differentiability. This proof helps us to more deeply understand this fundamental concept. In making sense of the chain rule, we turn it into a powerful tool in our mathematical toolkit.

contents.title: Quotient rule from product & chain rules
contents.description: We explore the connection between the quotient rule, product rule, and chain rule in calculus. Rather than memorizing another rule, we see how the quotient rule naturally emerges from applying the product and chain rules. This approach simplifies our understanding of these fundamental calculus tools.

topics.title: Differentiation: composite, implicit, and inverse functions: Unit test
topics.description: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

units.title: Contextual applications of differentiation
units.description: Derivatives describe the rate of change of quantities. This comes in handy when solving various problems that are related to rates of change in applied, real-world, situations. You'll also learn how to apply derivatives to approximate function values and find limits using L’Hôpital’s rule.

topics.title: Interpreting the meaning of the derivative in context

contents.title: Interpreting the meaning of the derivative in context
contents.description: Let's get hands-on with the concept of derivatives! We'll learn how to interpret the meaning of a derivative within a real-world context, turning complex calculus into practical applications. We'll see how derivatives can effectively express rates of change and motion in our everyday lives.

contents.title: Analyzing problems involving rates of change in applied contexts
contents.description: Differential calculus is all about instantaneous rate of change. Let's see how this can be used to solve real-world word problems.

contents.title: Interpreting the meaning of the derivative in context
contents.description: Interpreting expressions and situations involving derivatives in real world contexts.

topics.title: Straight-line motion: connecting position, velocity, and acceleration

contents.title: Introduction to one-dimensional motion with calculus
contents.description: Let's explore one-dimensional motion! We'll use calculus to connect position, velocity, speed, and acceleration. By understanding how position changes over time, we'll gain insights into the intricate dynamics of straight-line motion. It's all about making sense of movement in a one-dimensional world!

contents.title: Interpreting direction of motion from position-time graph
contents.description: Given the position-time graph of a linear motion, we can interpret whether the moving object moves forward or backward (or right or left, depending on how we define the motion!).

contents.title: Interpreting direction of motion from velocity-time graph
contents.description: Let's explore how a velocity-time graph can reveal the direction of an object's linear motion. We'll decipher whether the object is moving forward or backward, or even right or left, based on the graph's details. Together, we'll make sense of these intriguing mathematical representations of motion.

contents.title: Interpreting change in speed from velocity-time graph
contents.description: Let's examine a velocity-time graph to understand an object's motion. By distinguishing between positive and negative slopes, we discern whether the object is speeding up, slowing down, or maintaining its speed. It's a practical application of calculus concepts to real-world motion scenarios!

contents.title: Interpret motion graphs
contents.description: Interpret graphs that describe motion along a line.

contents.title: Worked example: Motion problems with derivatives
contents.description: Join us as we explore the relationship between position, velocity, and acceleration for a particle moving along the x-axis. We'll calculate velocity and acceleration from a given position function, and interpret these values to understand the particle's direction of motion and changes in speed. It's another practical application of calculus to real-world motion problems!

contents.title: Motion problems (differential calc)
contents.description: Practice analyzing a particle's position, velocity and acceleration.

topics.title: Rates of change in other applied contexts (non-motion problems)

contents.title: Applied rate of change: forgetfulness
contents.description: Let's face it—sometimes we forget things! Ever wonder about the dynamics underpinning this phenomenon? Let's explore this by tracking the number of vocabulary words remembered over time. Together, we'll use a mathematical model to calculate the rate of change in our memory, revealing the fascinating dynamics of knowledge retention and loss.

contents.title: Rates of change in other applied contexts (non-motion problems)
contents.description: Practice using derivatives in a variety of different fields.

contents.title: Marginal cost & differential calculus
contents.description: Through the lens of economics, we examine how the derivative can be used as a tool to understand marginal cost. We'll use a factory scenario to see how cost changes with quantity, and how this insight informs production decisions. Calculus—in real life!

topics.title: Contextual applications of differentiation: Quiz 1
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Introduction to related rates

contents.title: Related rates intro
contents.description: Join us as we explore the intriguing relationship between the rate at which a circle's radius expands and the corresponding rate of area growth. Using the tools of calculus, specifically derivatives, we'll tackle this concept, providing a practical application to real-world problems involving rates of change. This understanding forms a key part of mastering calculus and its applications.

contents.title: Analyzing problems involving related rates
contents.description: Related rates problems are word problems where we reason about the rate of change of a quantity by using information we have about the rate of change of another quantity that's related to it. Let's get acquainted with this sort of problem.

contents.title: Analyzing related rates problems: expressions
contents.description: Grasping related rates problems starts with understanding the quantities involved. In this exploration, we'll identify these quantities, match each expression with its units and values, and use this information to confidently tackle these problems. It's all about making sense of the relationships and changes over time.

contents.title: Analyzing related rates problems: expressions
contents.description: Analyze related rates problems to determine the appropriate value or units for various expressions used to solve the problem.

contents.title: Analyzing related rates problems: equations (Pythagoras)
contents.description: Mastering related rates problems hinges on the careful selection of an equation that accurately links the quantities. We'll illustrate this with a diagram, emphasizing the role of the right equation in solving these problems and understanding the interplay of quantities over time.

contents.title: Analyzing related rates problems: equations (trig)
contents.description: Let's tackle a practical problem involving a ladder sliding down a wall. We'll examine how the changing position of the ladder influences the angle it makes with the ground. We'll use calculus to calculate the rate of change of this angle. It's a hands-on way to see calculus in action!

contents.title: Analyzing related rates problems: equations
contents.description: Given a related rates problem, pick the appropriate equation to relate the relevant quantities.

contents.title: Differentiating related functions intro
contents.description: In this video, we explore how to differentiate related functions. We'll use the chain rule to find the derivatives of these functions, all linked to the same variable. It's a cool way to see how changes in one function can affect another.

contents.title: Worked example: Differentiating related functions
contents.description: In this video, we tackle a fascinating problem involving related functions. We'll explore how to use implicit differentiation to find the derivatives of these functions with respect to a shared variable. By the end, we'll have a clear understanding of how these functions interact and change together.

contents.title: Differentiate related functions
contents.description: Differentiate equations that relate multiple functions of the same variable. For example, differentiate A(t)=b(t)⋅h(t).

topics.title: Solving related rates problems

contents.title: Related rates intro
contents.description: Practice your understanding of related rates.

contents.title: Related rates (multiple rates)
contents.description: Solve related rates problems that involve three related quantities or more.

contents.title: Related rates: Approaching cars
contents.description: In this video, we explore the fascinating world of related rates with two cars approaching an intersection. We'll figure out how the rate of change of the distance between the two cars changes as they move. It's a real-world application of math that shows how calculus helps us understand motion and rates of change.

contents.title: Related rates: Falling ladder
contents.description: Let's explore a thrilling real-world scenario in this video: a ladder slipping away from a wall! We'll use related rates to calculate how fast the top of the ladder falls. It's a fun and practical application of calculus that'll keep us on our toes.

contents.title: Related rates (Pythagorean theorem)
contents.description: Solve related rates problem using the Pythagoream theorem.

contents.title: Related rates: water pouring into a cone
contents.description: In this video, we explore an intriguing scenario where we pour water into a cone-shaped cup at a constant rate. We'll discover how the rate of change in the water's depth connects to the rate of change in volume, all with the help of our new related rates tools.

contents.title: Related rates (advanced)
contents.description: Solve more elaborate problems with related rates.

contents.title: Related rates: shadow
contents.description: Let's take a look at a problem involving an owl hunting a mouse and the shadow it casts. We can use calculus to determine how fast the shadow moves as the owl dives towards its prey. It's a real-world application of related rates that brings the concept to life!

contents.title: Related rates: balloon
contents.description: Let's imagine we're at a hot air balloon show, and we're tracking a balloon's ascent. Using our knowledge of angles, distances, and related rates we can apply trigonometry and calculus to find the rate of change in the balloon's height.

topics.title: Contextual applications of differentiation: Quiz 2
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Approximating values of a function using local linearity and linearization

contents.title: Local linearity
contents.description: Sal introduces the idea of approximating curves using their tangent line equations. This is also called "local linearization."

contents.title: Local linearity and differentiability
contents.description: Intuition for how local linearity relates to differentiability using the Desmos graphing calculator.

contents.title: Worked example: Approximation with local linearity
contents.description: Finding the equation of a tangent line at a point of a curve by knowing the derivative at that point. Then using that equation to approximate the value of the function at close by x-values.

contents.title: Approximation with local linearity
contents.description: Practice approximating functions with local linearizations.

contents.title: Linear approximation of a rational function
contents.description: Sal finds a linear expression that approximates y=1/(x-1) around x=-1. This is done by finding the equation of the line tangent to the graph at x=-1, a process called "linear approximation."

topics.title: Using L’Hôpital’s rule for finding limits of indeterminate forms

contents.title: L'Hôpital's rule introduction
contents.description: When you are solving a limit, and get 0/0 or ∞/∞, L'Hôpital's rule is the tool you need.

contents.title: L'Hôpital's rule: limit at 0 example
contents.description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 0 of (2sin(x)-sin(2x))/(x-sin(x)).

contents.title: L'Hôpital's rule: 0/0
contents.description: Practice using L'Hopital's rule.

contents.title: L'Hôpital's rule: limit at infinity example
contents.description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at infinity of (4x²-5x)/(1-3x²).

contents.title: L'Hôpital's rule: ∞/∞
contents.description: Find limits at infinity using L'Hôpital's rule. For example, find the limit at infinity of eˣ/x².

contents.title: Proof of special case of l'Hôpital's rule

topics.title: Contextual applications of differentiation: Unit test
topics.description: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

units.title: Applying derivatives to analyze functions
units.description: The first and the second derivative of a function give us all sorts of useful information about that function's behavior. The first derivative tells us where a function increases or decreases or has a maximum or minimum value; the second derivative tells us where a function is concave up or down and where it has inflection points.

topics.title: Using the mean value theorem

contents.title: Mean value theorem
contents.description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in the interval (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b]. In other words, the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a,b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a,b].

contents.title: Mean value theorem example: polynomial
contents.description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=x²-6x+8 over the interval [2,5].

contents.title: Mean value theorem example: square root function
contents.description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=√(4x-3) over the interval [1,3].

contents.title: Using the mean value theorem
contents.description: Practice using the mean value theorem.

contents.title: Justification with the mean value theorem: table
contents.description: Example justifying use of mean value theorem (where function is defined with a table).

contents.title: Justification with the mean value theorem: equation
contents.description: Example justifying use of mean value theorem (where function is defined with an equation).

contents.title: Establishing differentiability for MVT
contents.description: A function must be differentiable for the mean value theorem to apply. Learn why this is so, and how to make sure the theorem can be applied in the context of a problem.

contents.title: Justification with the mean value theorem
contents.description: Given a table of values of a function, determine which conditions allow us to make certain conclusions based on the Mean Value Theorem.

contents.title: Mean value theorem application
contents.description: Even if a cop never spots you while you are speeding, he can still infer when you must have been speeding...

contents.title: Mean value theorem review
contents.description: Review your knowledge of the mean value theorem and use it to solve problems.

topics.title: Applying derivatives to analyze functions : Quiz 1
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Extreme value theorem, global versus local extrema, and critical points

contents.title: Extreme value theorem
contents.description: The Extreme value theorem states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval [a,b], then the function must have a maximum and a minimum on the interval. This makes sense: when a function is continuous you can draw its graph without lifting the pencil, so you must hit a high point and a low point on that interval.

contents.title: Critical points introduction
contents.description: Sal introduces the "critical points" of a function and discusses their relationship with the extremum points of the function.

contents.title: Finding critical points
contents.description: Sal finds the critical points of f(x)=xe^(-2x²).

contents.title: Find critical points
contents.description: Given the equation of a function, find where it has critical points.

topics.title: Determining intervals on which a function is increasing or decreasing

contents.title: Finding decreasing interval given the function
contents.description: Sal finds the intervals where the function f(x)=x⁶-3x⁵ is decreasing by analyzing the intervals where f' is positive or negative.

contents.title: Finding increasing interval given the derivative
contents.description: Sal is given that the derivative of function g, is g'(x)=x²/(x-2)³. He uses that to find the intervals where g is increasing, by looking for the intervals where g' is positive.

contents.title: Increasing & decreasing intervals
contents.description: Find the intervals in which a function (given algebraically) is increasing or decreasing.

contents.title: Increasing & decreasing intervals review
contents.description: Review how we use differential calculus to find the intervals where a function increases or decreases.

topics.title: Using the first derivative test to find relative (local) extrema

contents.title: Introduction to minimum and maximum points
contents.description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

contents.title: Finding relative extrema (first derivative test)
contents.description: Once you find a critical point, how can you tell if it is a minimum, maximum or neither?

contents.title: Worked example: finding relative extrema
contents.description: Sal finds the relative maximum point of g(x)=x⁴-x⁵ by analyzing the intervals where its derivative, g', is negative or positive.

contents.title: Analyzing mistakes when finding extrema (example 1)
contents.description: Analyzing the work of someone who tried to find extrema of a function, to see whether they made mistakes.

contents.title: Analyzing mistakes when finding extrema (example 2)
contents.description: Analyzing the work of someone who tried to find extrema of a function, to see whether they made mistakes.

contents.title: Finding relative extrema (first derivative test)
contents.description: The first derivative test is the process of analyzing functions using their first derivatives in order to find their extremum point. This involves multiple steps, so we need to unpack this process in a way that helps avoiding harmful omissions or mistakes.

contents.title: Relative minima & maxima
contents.description: Practice finding relative minima and maxima of functions given algebraically.

contents.title: Relative minima & maxima review
contents.description: Review how we use differential calculus to find relative extremum (minimum and maximum) points.

topics.title: Using the candidates test to find absolute (global) extrema

contents.title: Finding absolute extrema on a closed interval
contents.description: Sal finds the absolute maximum value of f(x)=8ln(x)-x² over the interval [1,4].

contents.title: Absolute minima & maxima (closed intervals)
contents.description: Find absolute minimum/maximum points of continuous functions over closed intervals.

contents.title: Absolute minima & maxima (entire domain)
contents.description: Sal analyzes the absolute minimum and maximum points of g(x)=x²ln(x) over its entire domain.

contents.title: Absolute minima & maxima (entire domain)
contents.description: Find absolute minimum/maximum points of continuous functions over their entire domain.

contents.title: Absolute minima & maxima review
contents.description: Review how we use differential calculus to find absolute extremum (minimum and maximum) points.

topics.title: Applying derivatives to analyze functions : Quiz 2
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Determining concavity of intervals and finding points of inflection: graphical

contents.title: Concavity introduction
contents.description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity, what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down," and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

contents.title: Analyzing concavity (graphical)
contents.description: Sal walks through an exercise where you are asked to recognize the concavity of a function in certain regions.

contents.title: Concavity intro
contents.description: Practice your understanding of concavity.

contents.title: Inflection points introduction
contents.description: Inflection points are points where the function changes concavity, i.e. from being "concave up" to being "concave down" or vice versa. They can be found by considering where the second derivative changes signs. In similar to critical points in the first derivative, inflection points will occur when the second derivative is either zero or undefined.

contents.title: Inflection points (graphical)
contents.description: Sal analyzes the graph of a function g to find all the inflection points of g.

contents.title: Inflection points intro
contents.description: Analyze the points of inflection of a function given the function's graph.

topics.title: Determining concavity of intervals and finding points of inflection: algebraic

contents.title: Analyzing concavity (algebraic)
contents.description: Sal finds the intervals where g(x)=-x⁴+6x²-2x-3 is concave down/up by finding where its second derivative, g'', is positive/negative.

contents.title: Inflection points (algebraic)
contents.description: Sal analyzes the points of inflection of g(x)=¼x⁴-4x³+24x² by looking for values where the second derivative g'' changes signs.

contents.title: Mistakes when finding inflection points: second derivative undefined
contents.description: Candidates for inflection points are points where the second derivative is zero *and* points where the second derivative is undefined. It's important not to overlook any candidate.

contents.title: Mistakes when finding inflection points: not checking candidates
contents.description: Candidates for inflection points are x-values where the second derivative is equal to zero or undefined. But they are only candidates! Once we've found them, we need to test them and see if they really are inflection points.

contents.title: Analyzing the second derivative to find inflection points
contents.description: Learn how the second derivative of a function is used in order to find the function's inflection points. Learn which common mistakes to avoid in the process.

contents.title: Analyze concavity
contents.description: Find intervals where a function (given algebraically) is concave up or down.

contents.title: Find inflection points
contents.description: Find points of inflection of functions given algebraically.

contents.title: Concavity review
contents.description: Review your knowledge of concavity of functions and how we use differential calculus to analyze it.

contents.title: Inflection points review
contents.description: Review your knowledge of inflection points and how we use differential calculus to find them.

topics.title: Using the second derivative test to find extrema

contents.title: Second derivative test
contents.description: Sal justifies the second derivative test, which is a way of determining relative minima & maxima, and gives an example.

contents.title: Second derivative test
contents.description: Practice using the second derivative test for extremum points.

topics.title: Sketching curves of functions and their derivatives

contents.title: Curve sketching with calculus: polynomial
contents.description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

contents.title: Curve sketching with calculus: logarithm
contents.description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=ln(x⁴+27) including extremum and inflection points.

contents.title: Analyzing a function with its derivative
contents.description: Taking the derivative of f(x)=x³-12x+2 and graphing the derivative, so we can tell when f is increasing or decreasing, and where is its relative extremum points.

topics.title: Applying derivatives to analyze functions : Quiz 3
