topics.title: Connecting a function, its first derivative, and its second derivative

contents.title: Calculus-based justification for function increasing
contents.description: A calculus-based justification is when we explain a property of a function f based on its derivative f'. See a good example (and a few wrong ones) for how to do this when explaining why a function increases.

contents.title: Justification using first derivative
contents.description: We can explain why a function is increasing, decreasing, or having a relative maximum using information about its first derivative. This is called calculus-based justification.

contents.title: Justification using first derivative
contents.description: Let's take a close look at how the behavior of a function is related to the behavior of its derivative. This type of reasoning is called "calculus-based reasoning." Learn how to apply it appropriately.

contents.title: Justification using first derivative
contents.description: Justify properties of functions based on their derivative.

contents.title: Inflection points from graphs of function & derivatives
contents.description: Identifying inflection points from graphs of function, first derivative and second derivative. Graphs are done using Desmos.com.

contents.title: Justification using second derivative: inflection point
contents.description: We can justify whether a function has an inflection point by looking at where the second derivative changes its sign.

contents.title: Justification using second derivative: maximum point
contents.description: Given that the derivative of a function is zero, we can justify whether the function has a relative maximum point by looking at the second derivative.

contents.title: Justification using second derivative
contents.description: "Calculus-based reasoning" with the second derivative of a function can be used to justify claims about the concavity of the original function and about its inflection points.

contents.title: Justification using second derivative
contents.description: Justify properties of functions based on their second (and first) derivatives.

contents.title: Connecting f, f', and f'' graphically
contents.description: Analyzing three graphs to see which describes the derivative of which other graph.

contents.title: Connecting f, f', and f'' graphically (another example)
contents.description: Analyzing three graphs to see which describes the derivative of which other graph.

contents.title: Connecting f, f', and f'' graphically
contents.description: Identify which of three given graphs describes a function, which describes the function's first derivative, and which describes the function's second derivative.

contents.title: Optimization: box volume (Part 1)

contents.title: Optimization: box volume (Part 2)
contents.description: Finishing up the last video by working through the formulas.

contents.title: Optimization: profit
contents.description: Who knows, you may end up running a shoe factory one day.  So it might not be a bad idea to know how to maximize profits.

contents.title: Optimization: cost of materials
contents.description: With all the storage you might have to handle for your shoe factory, I bet you'd also like to be able to minize the cost of storage.

contents.title: Optimization: area of triangle & square (Part 1)
contents.description: Sal constructs an equilateral triangle & a square whose bases are 100m together, such that their area is the smallest possible.

contents.title: Optimization: area of triangle & square (Part 2)

contents.title: Optimization
contents.description: Practice those optimization skills!

contents.title: Motion problems: finding the maximum acceleration
contents.description: The speed of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by v(t)=-t³+6t²+2t. Sal analyzes it to find the time when the particle's acceleration attains its maximum value.

topics.title: Exploring behaviors of implicit relations

contents.title: Horizontal tangent to implicit curve
contents.description: Finding the equation of a horizontal tangent to a curve that is defined implicitly as an equation in x and y.

contents.title: Tangents to graphs of implicit relations
contents.description: Find points on implicit curves where the tangent line is horizontal or vertical.

contents.title: Analyze functions (calculator-active)
contents.description: Analyze the behavior of graphs of functions using a graphing calculator and your knowledge about derivatives.

topics.title: Applying derivatives to analyze functions : Unit test
topics.description: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

units.title: Integration and accumulation of change
units.description: The definite integral is an important tool in calculus. It calculates the area under a curve, or the accumulation of a quantity over time. Riemann sums allow us to approximate integrals, while the fundamental theorem of calculus reveals how they connect to derivatives.

topics.title: Exploring accumulations of change

contents.title: Introduction to integral calculus
contents.description: The basic idea of Integral calculus is finding the area under a curve. To find it exactly, we can divide the area into infinite rectangles of infinitely small width and sum their areas—calculus is great for working with infinite things! This idea is actually quite rich, and it's also tightly related to Differential calculus, as you will see in the upcoming videos.

contents.title: Definite integrals intro
contents.description: Definite integrals represent the area under the curve of a function and above the 𝘹-axis. Learn about the notation we use to write them and see some introductory examples.

contents.title: Exploring accumulation of change
contents.description: Definite integrals are interpreted as the accumulation of quantities. Learn why this is so and how this can be used to analyze real-world contexts.

contents.title: Worked example: accumulation of change
contents.description: An example relating rates of change with a leaky bathtub.

contents.title: Accumulation of change
contents.description: Practice associating the area under rate-of-change curves with net change.

topics.title: Approximating areas with Riemann sums

contents.title: Riemann approximation introduction
contents.description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

contents.title: Over- and under-estimation of Riemann sums
contents.description: Riemann sums are approximations of area, so usually they aren't equal to the exact area. Sometimes they are larger than the exact area (this is called overestimation) and sometimes they are smaller (this is called underestimation).

contents.title: Left & right Riemann sums
contents.description: Areas under curves can be estimated with rectangles. Such estimations are called Riemann sums.

contents.title: Worked example: finding a Riemann sum using a table
contents.description: When we have a table of values of a function, we can use it to find a Riemann sum approximation of that function.

contents.title: Left & right Riemann sums
contents.description: Using rectangles to approximate the area under a curve practice problems

contents.title: Worked example: over- and under-estimation of Riemann sums
contents.description: Ordering different areas from least to greatest.

contents.title: Over- and under-estimation of Riemann sums
contents.description: Analyze Riemann sums of various functions to determine if they are an over-estimation or an under-estimation of the actual area.

contents.title: Midpoint sums
contents.description: Approximating area under a curve using rectangle where the heights are the value of the function at the midpoint of each interval.

contents.title: Trapezoidal sums
contents.description: The area under a curve is commonly approximated using rectangles (e.g. left, right, and midpoint Riemann sums), but it can also be approximated by trapezoids. Trapezoidal sums actually give a better approximation, in general, than rectangular sums that use the same number of subdivisions.

contents.title: Understanding the trapezoidal rule
contents.description: Walk through an example using the trapezoid rule, then try a couple of practice problems on your own.

contents.title: Midpoint & trapezoidal sums
contents.description: Trapezoid rule practice problems

contents.title: Riemann sums review
contents.description: Review how we use Riemann sums and the trapezoidal rule to approximate an area under a curve.

topics.title: Riemann sums, summation notation, and definite integral notation

contents.title: Summation notation
contents.description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

contents.title: Summation notation
contents.description: We can describe sums with multiple terms using the sigma operator, Σ. Learn how to evaluate sums written this way.

contents.title: Worked examples: Summation notation
contents.description: Summation notation uses the sigma Σ symbol to represent sums with multiple terms. See some more involved examples of how we read expressions in summation notation.

contents.title: Summation notation
contents.description: Practice your understanding of sigma notation of finite sums.

contents.title: Riemann sums in summation notation
contents.description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.

contents.title: Riemann sums in summation notation
contents.description: Summation notation can be used to write Riemann sums in a compact way. This is a challenging, yet important step towards a formal definition of the definite integral.

contents.title: Worked example: Riemann sums in summation notation
contents.description: Here we express the approximation of the area under a curve in sigma notation.

contents.title: Riemann sums in summation notation
contents.description: Riemann sums and sigma notation practice problems

contents.title: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum
contents.description: Definite integrals represent the exact area under a given curve, and Riemann sums are used to approximate those areas. However, if we take Riemann sums with infinite rectangles of infinitely small width (using limits), we get the exact area, i.e. the definite integral!

contents.title: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum
contents.description: Riemann sums help us approximate definite integrals, but they also help us formally define definite integrals. Learn how this is achieved and how we can move between the representation of area as a definite integral and as a Riemann sum.

contents.title: Worked example: Rewriting definite integral as limit of Riemann sum
contents.description: Given a definite integral expression, we can write the corresponding limit of a Riemann sum with infinite rectangles.

contents.title: Worked example: Rewriting limit of Riemann sum as definite integral
contents.description: When given a limit of Riemann sum with infinite rectangles, we can analyze the expression to find the corresponding definite integral.

contents.title: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum
contents.description: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum practice problems

topics.title: Integration and accumulation of change: Quiz 1

topics.title: The fundamental theorem of calculus and accumulation functions

contents.title: The fundamental theorem of calculus and accumulation functions
contents.description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

contents.title: Functions defined by definite integrals (accumulation functions)
contents.description: Understanding that a function can be defined using a definite integral. Thinking about how to evaluate functions defined this way.

contents.title: Functions defined by definite integrals (accumulation functions)
contents.description: Use a graph to evaluate functions defined by integrals.

contents.title: Finding derivative with fundamental theorem of calculus
contents.description: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus tells us that the derivative of the definite integral from 𝘢 to 𝘹 of ƒ(𝑡)𝘥𝑡 is ƒ(𝘹), provided that ƒ is continuous. See how this can be used to evaluate the derivative of accumulation functions.

contents.title: Finding derivative with fundamental theorem of calculus
contents.description: Fundamental theorem of calculus practice problems

contents.title: Finding derivative with fundamental theorem of calculus: chain rule
contents.description: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus tells us how to find the derivative of the integral from 𝘢 to 𝘹 of a certain function. But what if instead of 𝘹 we have a function of 𝘹, for example sin(𝘹)? Then we need to also use the chain rule.

contents.title: Finding derivative with fundamental theorem of calculus: chain rule
contents.description: Use the chain rule and the fundamental theorem of calculus to find the derivative of definite integrals with lower or upper limits other than x.

topics.title: Interpreting the behavior of accumulation functions involving area

contents.title: Interpreting the behavior of accumulation functions
contents.description: When given the graph of function ƒ, we can reason about the graph of its antiderivative 𝑔 (so 𝑔'=ƒ).

contents.title: Interpreting the behavior of accumulation functions
contents.description: We can apply "calculus-based reasoning" to justify properties of the antiderivative of a function using our knowledge about the original function.

contents.title: Interpreting the behavior of accumulation functions
contents.description: Given the graph of a function, pick the appropriate justification for certain properties of an antiderivative of the function.

topics.title: Applying properties of definite integrals

contents.title: Negative definite integrals
contents.description: We learned that definite integrals give us the area under the curve and above the x-axis. But what if the curve itself is below the x-axis? In this case, the definite integral is still related to area, but it's negative. See how this works and get some intuition for why this is so.

contents.title: Finding definite integrals using area formulas
contents.description: Since definite integrals are the net area between a curve and the x-axis, we can sometimes use geometric area formulas to find definite integrals. See how it's done.

contents.title: Finding definite integrals using area formulas
contents.description: Practice evaluating definite integrals by finding the area using shapes (like rectangles & circles) under a function.

contents.title: Definite integral over a single point
contents.description: What happens when the bounds of your integral are the same?

contents.title: Integrating scaled version of function
contents.description: Sal uses a graph to explain why we can take a constant out of a definite integral.

contents.title: Switching bounds of definite integral
contents.description: What happens when you swap the bounds on an integral?

contents.title: Integrating sums of functions
contents.description: If you know the integrals of two functions, what is the integral of their sum?

contents.title: Worked examples: Finding definite integrals using algebraic properties
contents.description: Sal evaluates definite integrals of functions given their graphs. He does so using various properties of integrals.

contents.title: Finding definite integrals using algebraic properties
contents.description: Properties of integrals practice problems

contents.title: Definite integrals on adjacent intervals
contents.description: By subdividing the stretch of numbers where you are integrating, you can break up an integral.

contents.title: Worked example: Breaking up the integral's interval
contents.description: Finding a definite integral by breaking it down to smaller intervals that are adjacent to each other.

contents.title: Worked example: Merging definite integrals over adjacent intervals
contents.description: Thinking about how to evaluate the sum of definite integrals over adjacent intervals.

contents.title: Definite integrals over adjacent intervals
contents.description: Practice your understanding of definite integral properties: integrating sums of functions, and taking the integral of a function multiplied by a constant.

contents.title: Functions defined by integrals: switched interval
contents.description: Sal evaluates a function defined by the integral of a graphed function. In order to evaluate he must switch the sides of the interval.

contents.title: Finding derivative with fundamental theorem of calculus: x is on lower bound
contents.description: Sometimes you need to swap the bounds of integration before applying the fundamental theorem of calculus.

contents.title: Finding derivative with fundamental theorem of calculus: x is on both bounds
contents.description: How do you apply the fundamental theorem of calculus when both integral bounds are a function of x.

contents.title: Definite integrals properties review
contents.description: Review the definite integral properties and use them to solve problems.

contents.title: The fundamental theorem of calculus and definite integrals
contents.description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus, and we go through the connection here.

contents.title: The fundamental theorem of calculus and definite integrals
contents.description: Use the fundamental theorem of calculus to find definite integrals.

contents.title: Antiderivatives and indefinite integrals
contents.description: What's the opposite of a derivative?  It's something called the "indefinite integral".

topics.title: Finding antiderivatives and integrals: basic rules and notation: reverse power rule

contents.title: Reverse power rule
contents.description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

contents.title: Reverse power rule
contents.description: For example, find the indefinite integral of t².

contents.title: Reverse power rule: negative and fractional powers
contents.description: For example, find the indefinite integral of x^(-2)  or x^(3/4).

contents.title: Indefinite integrals: sums & multiples
contents.description: An indefinite integral of a sum is the same as the sum of the integrals of the component parts. Constants can be "taken out" of integrals.

contents.title: Reverse power rule: sums & multiples
contents.description: Find the indefinite integrals of polynomials.

contents.title: Rewriting before integrating
contents.description: Some indefinite integrals are much simpler to integrate by algebraically rewriting the integrand first.

contents.title: Reverse power rule: rewriting before integrating
contents.description: Find indefinite integrals using the reverse power rule. The integrands in this exercise need to be rewritten before the reverse power rule can be applied.

contents.title: Reverse power rule review
contents.description: Review your knowledge of the reverse power rule for integrals and solve problems with it.

topics.title: Finding antiderivatives and integrals: basic rules and notation: common indefinite integrals

contents.title: Indefinite integral of 1/x
contents.description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

contents.title: Indefinite integrals of sin(x), cos(x), and eˣ
contents.description: ∫sin(x)dx=-cos(x)+C, ∫cos(x)dx=sin(x)+C, and ∫eˣdx=eˣ+C. Learn why this is so and see worked examples.

contents.title: Indefinite integrals: eˣ & 1/x
contents.description: For example, find the indefinite integral of 4eˣ-3/x.

contents.title: Indefinite integrals: sin & cos
contents.description: For example, find the indefinite integral of 5cos(x).

contents.title: Common integrals review
contents.description: Review the integration rules for all the common function types.

topics.title: Finding antiderivatives and integrals: basic rules and notation: definite integrals

contents.title: Definite integrals: reverse power rule
contents.description: Examples of calculating definite integrals of polynomials using the fundamental theorem of calculus and the reverse power rule.

contents.title: Definite integrals: reverse power rule
contents.description: Evaluating definite integrals using the fundamental theorem of calculus

contents.title: Definite integral of rational function
contents.description: Sal finds the definite integral of (16-x³)/x³ between -1 and -2 using the reverse power rule.

contents.title: Definite integral of radical function
contents.description: Sal finds the definite integral of 12∛x between -1 and 8 using the reverse power rule.

contents.title: Definite integral of trig function
contents.description: Sal finds the definite integral of 9sin(x) between 11π/2 and 6π.

contents.title: Definite integral involving natural log
contents.description: Sal finds the definite integral of (6+x²)/x³ between 2 and 4. To do that, he has to use the integral of 1/x, which is ln(x).

contents.title: Definite integrals: common functions
contents.description: Evaluate definite integrals with a variety of functions including rational, square root, cube root, exponential, and natural logs.

contents.title: Definite integral of piecewise function
contents.description: Sal evaluates definite integral of a piecewise function over an interval that goes through the two cases of the function.

contents.title: Definite integral of absolute value function
contents.description: Sal evaluates the definite integral of f(x)=|x+2| between -4 and 0.

contents.title: Definite integrals of piecewise functions
contents.description: Evaluate definite integrals of piecewise functions.

topics.title: Integration and accumulation of change: Quiz 4
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Integrating using substitution

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution intro
contents.description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: multiplying by a constant
contents.description: Manipulating the expression to make u-substitution a little more obvious.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: defining 𝘶
contents.description: A common challenge when performing 𝘶-substitution is to realize which part should be our 𝘶.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: defining 𝘶 (more examples)
contents.description: A common challenge when performing 𝘶-substitution is to realize which part should be our 𝘶.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution
contents.description: 𝘶-Substitution essentially reverses the chain rule for derivatives. In other words, it helps us integrate composite functions.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: defining 𝘶
contents.description: Given an integral that should be found using u-substitution, determine what u should be.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: rational function
contents.description: Another example of using u-substitution

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: logarithmic function
contents.description: Doing u-substitution with ln(x)

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution warmup
contents.description: Before diving into our practice exercise, gain some risk-free experience performing 𝘶-substitution.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: indefinite integrals
contents.description: Find indefinite integrals that require using the method of 𝘶-substitution.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: definite integrals
contents.description: When using 𝘶-substitution in definite integrals, we must make sure we take care of the boundaries of integration.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: definite integrals
contents.description: Find definite integrals that require using the method of 𝘶-substitution.

contents.title: 𝘶-substitution: definite integral of exponential function
contents.description: Finding the definite integral from 0 to 1 of x²⋅2^(x³).

topics.title: Integrating functions using long division and completing the square

contents.title: Integration using long division
contents.description: Here we do polynomial long division to make an integral more computable.

contents.title: Integration using long division
contents.description: Find indefinite integrals of rational functions by using polynomial long division.

contents.title: Integration using completing the square and the derivative of arctan(x)
contents.description: Sometimes we can integrate rational functions by using the method of completing the square in the denominator and then integrating using u-substitution and our knowledge about the derivative of arctan(x).

contents.title: Integration using completing the square
contents.description: Find indefinite integrals of rational functions of the form 1/p(x) or 1/√p(x), where p(x) is a quadratic function, by completing the square in p(x).

topics.title: Integration and accumulation of change: Quiz 5
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Optional videos

contents.title: Proof of fundamental theorem of calculus
contents.description: The first part of the fundamental theorem of calculus tells us that if we define 𝘍(𝘹) to be the definite integral of function ƒ from some constant 𝘢 to 𝘹, then 𝘍 is an antiderivative of ƒ. In other words, 𝘍'(𝘹)=ƒ(𝘹). See why this is so.

contents.title: Intuition for second part of fundamental theorem of calculus
contents.description: The second part of the fundamental theorem of calculus tells us that to find the definite integral of a function ƒ from 𝘢 to 𝘣, we need to take an antiderivative of ƒ, call it 𝘍, and calculate 𝘍(𝘣)-𝘍(𝘢). Get some intuition into why this is true.

topics.title: Integration and accumulation of change: Unit test
topics.description: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

units.title: Differential equations
units.description: Differential equations are equations that include both a function and its derivative (or higher-order derivatives). For example, y=y' is a differential equation. Learn how to find and represent solutions of basic differential equations.

topics.title: Modeling situations with differential equations

contents.title: Differential equations introduction
contents.description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

contents.title: Writing a differential equation
contents.description: Differential equations describe relationships that involve quantities and their rates of change. See how we write the equation for such a relationship.

contents.title: Write differential equations
contents.description: Write differential equations based on the description of a relationship between two quantities.

topics.title: Verifying solutions for differential equations

contents.title: Verifying solutions to differential equations
contents.description: We can check whether a potential solution to a differential equation is indeed a solution. What we need to do is differentiate and substitute both the solution and the derivative into the equation.

contents.title: Verify solutions to differential equations
contents.description: Solve some basic problems about checking or finding particular and general solutions to differential equations.

topics.title: Sketching slope fields

contents.title: Slope fields introduction
contents.description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

contents.title: Worked example: equation from slope field
contents.description: Given a slope field and a few differential equations, we can determine which equation corresponds to the slope field by considering specific slopes.

contents.title: Worked example: slope field from equation
contents.description: Given a differential equation in x and y, we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x,y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we match an equation to its slope field by considering the various slopes in the diagram.

contents.title: Worked example: forming a slope field
contents.description: Given a differential equation in x and y, we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x,y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we determine the slopes of a few segments in the slope field of an equation.

contents.title: Slope fields & equations
contents.description: Work on the relationship between differential equations and the slope field that represents them.

topics.title: Reasoning using slope fields

contents.title: Approximating solution curves in slope fields
contents.description: Given the slope field of a differential equation, we can sketch various solutions to the equation.

contents.title: Worked example: range of solution curve from slope field
contents.description: Given the slope field of a differential equation, we can sketch various solutions to the equation. In this example, we analyze the range of a specific solution.

contents.title: Reasoning using slope fields
contents.description: Analyze slope fields that describe differential equations in order to find particular or general solutions to those equations.

topics.title: Differential equations: Quiz 1
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Finding general solutions using separation of variables

contents.title: Separable equations introduction
contents.description: "Separation of variables" allows us to rewrite differential equations so we obtain an equality between two integrals we can evaluate. Separable equations are the class of differential equations that can be solved using this method.

contents.title: Addressing treating differentials algebraically
contents.description: Addressing treating differentials algebraically

contents.title: Separable differential equations
contents.description: Separation of variables is a common method for solving differential equations. Learn how it's done and why it's called this way.

contents.title: Separable differential equations: find the error
contents.description: Analyze the work of students using separation of variables to find whether their work is incorrect and if so, why.

contents.title: Worked example: separable differential equations
contents.description: Two worked examples of finding general solutions to separable differential equations.

contents.title: Separable differential equations
contents.description: Solve differential equations using separation of variables.

contents.title: Worked example: identifying separable equations
contents.description: Separable equations can be written in the form dy/dx=f(x)g(y). See how we analyze various differential equations to see if they are separable.

contents.title: Identify separable equations
contents.description: Given a differential equation, determine whether it can be solved using separation of variables.

topics.title: Finding particular solutions using initial conditions and separation of variables

contents.title: Particular solutions to differential equations: rational function
contents.description: Sal finds f(-1) given that f'(x)=24/x³ and f(2)=12.

contents.title: Particular solutions to differential equations: exponential function
contents.description: Sal finds f(0) given that f'(x)=5eˣ and f(7)=40+5e⁷.

contents.title: Particular solutions to differential equations
contents.description: Practice finding what that little "+c" should be when your integral is used for a real problem.

contents.title: Worked example: finding a specific solution to a separable equation
contents.description: Solving a separable differential equation given initial conditions. In this video, the equation is dy/dx=2y² with y(1)=1.

contents.title: Worked example: separable equation with an implicit solution
contents.description: Sometimes the solution of a separable differential equation can't be written as an explicit function. This doesn't mean we can't use it!

contents.title: Particular solutions to separable differential equations
contents.description: Solve and analyze separable differential equations, like dy/dx=x²y.

topics.title: Exponential models with differential equations

contents.title: Exponential models & differential equations (Part 1)
contents.description: Assuming a quantity grows proportionally to its size results in the general equation dy/dx=ky. Solving it with separation of variables results in the general exponential function y=Ceᵏˣ.

contents.title: Exponential models & differential equations (Part 2)
contents.description: Given the general solution P=Ceᵏᵗ and the conditions P(0)=100 and P(50)=200, we find the solution to an exponential modeling problem.

contents.title: Worked example: exponential solution to differential equation
contents.description: The solution of the general differential equation dy/dx=ky (for some k) is C⋅eᵏˣ (for some C). See how this is derived and used for finding a particular solution to a differential equation.

contents.title: Differential equations: exponential model equations
contents.description: Solve differential equations that describe exponential relationships. Such equations always have the form dy/dx=ky (for some number k).

contents.title: Differential equations: exponential model word problems
contents.description: Solve word problems that involve differential equations of exponential growth and decay.

topics.title: Differential equations: Quiz 2
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Differential equations: Unit test
topics.description: Test your understanding of {unit name}.

units.title: Applications of integration
units.description: Definite integrals are all about the accumulation of quantities. Let's see how they are applied in order to solve various kinds of problems.

topics.title: Finding the average value of a function on an interval

contents.title: Average value over a closed interval
contents.description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

contents.title: Calculating average value of function over interval
contents.description: Here we find the average value of x^2+1 on the interval between 0 and 3.

contents.title: Average value of a function
contents.description: Average value of a function practice problems.

contents.title: Mean value theorem for integrals
contents.description: Here Sal goes through the connection between the mean value theorem and integration.

topics.title: Connecting position, velocity, and acceleration functions using integrals

contents.title: Motion problems with integrals: displacement vs. distance
contents.description: The definite integral of a velocity function gives us the displacement. To find the actual distance traveled, we need to use the speed function, which is the absolute value of the velocity.

contents.title: Analyzing motion problems: position
contents.description: Finding the appropriate expression to use when looking for the position at a certain time.

contents.title: Analyzing motion problems: total distance traveled
contents.description: Finding the appropriate expression to use when looking for the total distance traveled over a certain time interval.

contents.title: Motion problems (with definite integrals)
contents.description: Definite integrals are commonly used to solve motion problems, for example, by reasoning about a moving object's position given information about its velocity. Learn how this is done and about the crucial difference of velocity and speed.

contents.title: Analyzing motion problems (integral calculus)
contents.description: Given a motion problem, find the expression that can be used in order to solve the problem.

contents.title: Worked example: motion problems (with definite integrals)
contents.description: What can you say about the velocity and position of a particle given its acceleration.

contents.title: Motion problems (with integrals)
contents.description: Apply what you've learned about integration to solve a variety of particle motion problems.

contents.title: Average acceleration over interval
contents.description: As an example of finding a mean value, we find an average acceleration.

topics.title: Using accumulation functions and definite integrals in applied contexts

contents.title: Area under rate function gives the net change
contents.description: If you have a function representing rate, what does the area under its curve represent?

contents.title: Interpreting definite integral as net change
contents.description: The definite integral of a rate function gives us the net change in the quantity described by the rate. See how we interpret definite integrals in a real-world context.

contents.title: Worked examples: interpreting definite integrals in context
contents.description: Interpreting expressions involving definite integrals in a real-world context.

contents.title: Interpreting definite integrals in context
contents.description: Given a function that models a real-world context, interpret the meaning of various expressions and statements that involve the integral of the function.

contents.title: Analyzing problems involving definite integrals
contents.description: See worked example of how to find the appropriate expression to use in order to solve word problems using definite integrals.

contents.title: Analyzing problems involving definite integrals
contents.description: The interpretation of definite integrals as accumulation of quantities can be used to solve various real-world word problems.

contents.title: Analyzing problems involving definite integrals
contents.description: Given a word problem that involves rates and accumulation, find the appropriate expression for solving the problem.

contents.title: Worked example: problem involving definite integral (algebraic)
contents.description: Using definite integral to solve a word problem about the growth in the population of a town.

contents.title: Problems involving definite integrals (algebraic)
contents.description: Solve real-world problems that involve rate of change and net change using integral calculus.

topics.title: Applications of integration: Quiz 1
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Finding the area between curves expressed as functions of x

contents.title: Area between a curve and the x-axis
contents.description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

contents.title: Area between a curve and the x-axis: negative area
contents.description: With integrals, it can be helpful to introduce the notion of "negative area".  See why!

contents.title: Area between a curve and the x-axis
contents.description: Area between curve and axis practice problems.

contents.title: Area between curves
contents.description: By integrating the difference of two functions, you can find the area between them.

contents.title: Worked example: area between curves
contents.description: The area between the graphs of functions ƒ and 𝑔 can be found by taking the definite integral of ƒ-𝑔 (suppose ƒ is above 𝑔).

contents.title: Area between two curves given end points
contents.description: Calculate the area that's bounded by functions from above and below. In this exercise, the right and left endpoints of the area are given.

contents.title: Area between two curves
contents.description: Calculate the area that's bounded by functions from above and below. In this exercise, the right and left endpoints of the area are not given.

contents.title: Composite area between curves
contents.description: Sometimes we need to break the area into multiple different areas, because the enclosing functions change.

topics.title: Finding the area between curves expressed as functions of y

contents.title: Area between a curve and the 𝘺-axis
contents.description: We can use a definite integral in terms of 𝘺 to find the area between a curve and the 𝘺-axis.

contents.title: Horizontal area between curves
contents.description: We can use a definite integral in terms of 𝘺 to find the horizontal area between curves of two functions of 𝘺.

contents.title: Horizontal areas between curves
contents.description: Find the horizontal area between a given curve and the y-axis.

topics.title: Finding the area between curves that intersect at more than two points

contents.title: Area between curves that intersect at more than two points (calculator-active)
contents.description: Use definite integrals to find area between curves that intersect at more than two points.

topics.title: Applications of integration: Quiz 2
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

topics.title: Volumes with cross sections: squares and rectangles

contents.title: Volume with cross sections: intro
contents.description: Using definite integration to find volume of a solid whose base is given as a region between function and whose cross sections are squares.

contents.title: Volumes with cross sections: squares and rectangles (intro)
contents.description: Find volumes of solids with a given base and a common shape for all cross sections. In this exercise, cross section shapes are either squares or rectangles.

contents.title: Volume with cross sections: squares and rectangles (no graph)
contents.description: Expressing the volume of a 3-D figure as a definite integral (where the area of cross sections are functions of x). The problem doesn't come with a graph but that doesn't mean we shouldn't sketch one!

contents.title: Volume with cross sections perpendicular to y-axis
contents.description: Worked example expressing the volume of a figure based on cross sections perpendicular to the y-axis as a definite integral (integrating with respect to y).

contents.title: Volumes with cross sections: squares and rectangles
contents.description: Find volumes of solids whose base is given along with information about the shape of their cross sections.

topics.title: Volumes with cross sections: triangles and semicircles

contents.title: Volume with cross sections: semicircle
contents.description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

contents.title: Volume with cross sections: triangle
contents.description: This time, the cross section of our solid is given as the area between two curves.

contents.title: Volumes with cross sections: triangles and semicircles
contents.description: Find volumes of solids with a given base and a common shape for all cross sections. In this exercise, cross section shapes are either triangles or semicircles.

topics.title: Volume with disc method: revolving around x- or y-axis

contents.title: Disc method around x-axis
contents.description: Finding the solid of revolution (constructed by revolving around the x-axis) using the disc method.

contents.title: Generalizing disc method around x-axis
contents.description: Generalizing what we did in the last video for f(x) to get the "formula" for using the disc method around the x-axis

contents.title: Disc method around y-axis
contents.description: Finding the volume of a figure that is rotated around the y-axis using the disc method

contents.title: Disc method: revolving around x- or y-axis
contents.description: Calculate the volume of bodies of revolution using the disc method.

topics.title: Volume with disc method: revolving around other axes

contents.title: Disc method rotation around horizontal line
contents.description: Solid of revolution constructing by rotating around line that is not an axis

contents.title: Disc method rotating around vertical line
contents.description: Volume of solid created by rotating around vertical line that is not the y-axis using the disc method.

contents.title: Calculating integral disc around vertical line
contents.description: Calculate the integral from the last video.

contents.title: Disc method: revolving around other axes
contents.description: Find volumes of solids of revolution around any horizontal or vertical line using the disc method.

topics.title: Volume with washer method: revolving around x- or y-axis

contents.title: Solid of revolution between two functions (leading up to the washer method)
contents.description: Finding the volume of a solid of revolution that is defined between two functions

contents.title: Generalizing the washer method
contents.description: Looking at the example from the last video in a more generalized way

contents.title: Washer method: revolving around x- or y-axis
contents.description: Calculate the volume of bodies of revolution using the washer method.

topics.title: Volume with washer method: revolving around other axes

contents.title: Washer method rotating around horizontal line (not x-axis), part 1
contents.description: Washer method when rotating around a horizontal line that is not the x-axis

contents.title: Washer method rotating around horizontal line (not x-axis), part 2
contents.description: Doing some hairy algebra and arithmetic to evaluate the definite integral from the last video

contents.title: Washer method rotating around vertical line (not y-axis), part 1
contents.description: Setting up the definite integral for the volume of a solid of revolution around a vertical line using the "washer" or "ring" method.

contents.title: Washer method rotating around vertical line (not y-axis), part 2
contents.description: Evaluating the integral set up in the last video using washer method.

contents.title: Washer method: revolving around other axes
contents.description: Find volumes of solids of revolution around any horizontal or vertical line using the washer method.

contents.title: Contextual and analytical applications of integration (calculator-active)
contents.description: Solve various problems that involve definite integrals using a graphing calculator.
